content:
• Sam has IP Extend with a Benefit Amount of $5,000 per month (the Increasing Claim Option was not selected by Sam so does not apply).
• Sam was 45 years old when he suffered a Sickness or Injury and was medically certified Totally Unable to Work in his Own Occupation.
• For the first 24 months of the Claim Period, the Totally Unable to Work Benefit payable is: Benefit Amount = $5,000 per month
• From the 25th month to the 30th month of the Claim Period, Sam remained Totally Unable to Work in Any Occupation. The Totally Unable to Work Benefit payable is: = $5,000 per month
• On the 31st month of the Claim Period, Sam was able to return to work two days a week earning $2,800 per month. The Partially Unable to Work Benefit payable is: Benefit Amount – 100% of Earnings = $5,000 – (100% x $2,800) = $2,200 per month
• From the 35th month onwards, Sam returned to full-time work and his claim was finalised.
ai_summary: Sam holds an IP Extend policy with a $5,000 monthly benefit amount and was certified Totally Unable to Work due to Sickness or Injury at age 45. For the first 24 months, he received $5,000 monthly, continuing at the same rate from months 25 to 30. In the 31st month, after returning to part-time work earning $2,800 monthly, his benefit was adjusted to $2,200. His claim concluded when he returned to full-time work from the 35th month onward.

content:
• Michael has IP Extend with a Benefit Amount of $7,000 per month (the Increasing Claim Option was not selected by Michael so does not apply).
• Michael was 61 years old when he suffered a Sickness or Injury and was medically certified Totally Unable to Work in his Own Occupation.
• For the first 24 months of the Claim Period, Michael remained Totally Unable to Work in his Own Occupation. He was paid the Totally Unable to Work Benefit at $7,000 per month.
• From the 25th month to the 28th month of the Claim Period, Michael remained Totally Unable to Work in Any Occupation.
• Since the claim started after the Policy anniversary before Michael’s 60th birthday, the Totally Unable to Work Benefit payable was: 2/3 x Benefit Amount = 2/3 x $7,000 = $4,666.67 per month
• Michael will continue to be paid the Totally Unable to Work Benefit until the end of his Benefit Period (to age 65), as long as he meets the requirements for the Totally Unable to Work Benefit.
ai_summary: Michael, aged 61, holds an IP Extend policy with a monthly Benefit Amount of $7,000 and is certified Totally Unable to Work due to Sickness or Injury. He received the full benefit for the first 24 months, and from months 25 to 28, his benefit adjusted to $4,666.67 per month, calculated as 2/3 of the original amount, since the claim began after his 60th birthday. Michael will continue to receive benefits until age 65, provided he meets the criteria for the Totally Unable to Work Benefit.

content:
Once you’ve decided on the type of Plan(s) you need, you need to decide:
• Whether the ownership is through superannuation or outside superannuation.
• How to structure your Plan(s) – Standalone, Attached, Linked or Superlink.
ai_summary: In structuring your Accelerated Protection Plan, you must determine whether to hold the ownership through superannuation or outside of it. Additionally, you should choose the structure of your Plan(s), which can be Standalone, Attached, Linked, or Superlink, each offering different benefits and implications for coverage and access.

content:
There are a few different ownership options available depending on the Plan you choose. The different types of ownership determine how the premiums are funded and may have different tax implications in respect of the premiums and benefits paid. An adviser can help you decide which ownership option is suitable to meet your needs. More information on tax and structuring insurance through superannuation can be found in Section 7 and Section 8. If you are structuring your Accelerated Protection insurance through TAL Super, you must also read the ‘Accelerated Protection through TAL Super PDS’.

Ownership structure | Life Insurance | TPD Insurance | Critical Illness Insurance | Child’s Critical Illness Insurance | Income Protection

Superannuation | ✓ | ✓ | ✗ | ✗ | ✓

ai_summary: The ownership structure for Accelerated Protection insurance offers various options—individual, superannuation, trust, company/business, joint, and parent/guardian—each affecting premium funding and tax implications differently. An adviser can assist in selecting the most suitable option based on individual needs, with additional details on tax and insurance structuring available in Sections 7 and 8. For those using TAL Super, it is essential to consult the 'Accelerated Protection through TAL Super PDS' for specific requirements.

content:
There are several different ways you can structure your Plans. An adviser can help you decide which Plan structure is suitable for your needs. The Plans structures available are:
• Standalone: A claim paid under a Standalone Plan will not reduce the Benefit Amount of another Standalone Plan.
• Attached/Attaching: When a Plan is Attached to another Plan, a claim paid under an Attached Plan will reduce the Benefit Amount on all other Plans that it is Attached to. All Attached Plans have the same Policy Owner(s) and are issued under one Policy.
• Linked/Linking: When a Plan is Linked to another Plan, a claim paid under a Linked Plan will reduce the Benefit Amount on all other Plans that it is Linked to. Linked Plans have different Policy Owners and the Plans are issued under multiple policies. This allows you to package Plans that cannot be structured through superannuation with Plans that are structured through superannuation.
• Superlink: Two policies are issued, one structured through superannuation and the other outside of superannuation. The Benefit Amount for both policies must be the same and the maximum benefit payable is the equivalent to the Benefit Amount of one Policy. This allows a portion of the premium to be funded through superannuation, thereby reducing out-of-pocket cost while still providing access to benefits that are not available when insurance is structured through superannuation.

If you make a claim and Superlink applies, we will assess the claim against the Policy structured through superannuation first. If a benefit is payable and the SIS legislation and rules are met, we will pay the benefits from the Policy structured through superannuation. If a benefit is payable but the SIS legislation and rules are not met, we will pay the benefits from the Policy structured outside superannuation.
ai_summary: The document outlines various Plan structures for insurance, including Standalone, Attached/Attaching, Linked/Linking, and Superlink options. Standalone Plans maintain separate Benefit Amounts, while Attached Plans reduce benefits across linked policies with the same owners. Linked Plans allow for different owners under multiple policies, facilitating the combination of superannuation and non-superannuation structured Plans. The Superlink structure involves two policies—one through superannuation and one outside—requiring equal Benefit Amounts, allowing premium funding through superannuation to lower costs. Claims under Superlink are assessed first against the superannuation policy, adhering to SIS legislation, with benefits payable from the appropriate policy based on compliance.

content: This table illustrates the available plan structures for Accelerated Protection when structured outside superannuation. It shows whether Life Insurance, TPD Insurance, Critical Illness Insurance, Child's Critical Illness Insurance, and Income Protection can be Standalone, Attached, Linked, or Superlink. Footnotes clarify that TPD, Critical Illness, and Child's Critical Illness can only be Attached/Linked to Life Insurance or Critical Illness Insurance.
ai_summary: The table outlines the structuring options for Accelerated Protection insurance outside superannuation, detailing that Life Insurance can be offered as Standalone, Attached, Linked, or Superlink, while TPD, Critical Illness, and Child's Critical Illness Insurance can only be structured as Attached or Linked to either Life Insurance or Critical Illness Insurance. This structure provides flexibility in coverage while specifying the interdependencies between different insurance types.

content: This diagram, titled 'STRUCTURING YOUR INSURANCE OUTSIDE SUPERANNUATION', describes the plan structures available when Accelerated Protection is structured outside superannuation. It outlines a three-step process: STEP 1 (Choose one or more insurance plans: Life, TPD, Critical Illness, Child's Critical Illness, Income Protection), STEP 2 (Choose optional benefits), and STEP 3 (Choose optional attached plans: TPD, Critical Illness, Child's Critical Illness).

Step 1 involves selecting from various insurance options, including Life, Total and Permanent Disability (TPD), Critical Illness, Child's Critical Illness, and Income Protection. Step 2 allows for the addition of optional benefits, while Step 3 offers the choice of attaching further plans such as TPD, Critical Illness, and Child's Critical Illness, enhancing coverage flexibility and customization.

content: You should be aware of the following if you structure Accelerated Protection through superannuation: You will need to be a member of the superannuation fund through which your Policy is structured. The trustee of the fund owns the Policy. Premiums and benefit payments are made through the fund and are subjected to restrictions under the governing rules of the fund and in accordance with superannuation law. Some features of Accelerated Protection will not be available or will not apply. For a claim to be paid, you must fulfil the SIS rules and regulations, and the applicable SIS definitions (refer to Section 9.2). A claim under TPD Insurance must meet the SIS definition of Permanent Incapacity. A claim under Income Protection must meet the SIS definition of Temporary Incapacity. The following diagram describes the Plans structures available when Accelerated Protection is structured through superannuation.
ai_summary: When structuring Accelerated Protection through superannuation, you must be a member of the fund, as the trustee owns the policy and manages premiums and benefit payments according to superannuation law. Certain features may be unavailable, and claims must comply with SIS rules; for instance, Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) claims require meeting the SIS definition of Permanent Incapacity, while Income Protection claims must align with the definition of Temporary Incapacity.

content: This diagram, titled 'STRUCTURING YOUR INSURANCE THROUGH SUPERANNUATION', illustrates the plan structures available when Accelerated Protection is structured through superannuation. It outlines a four-step process: STEP 1 (Choose one or more insurance plans: Life, TPD, Income Protection), STEP 2 (Choose optional benefits), STEP 3 (Choose optional attached/linked plans: TPD, Critical Illness), and STEP 4 (Choose Linked Policies structured outside superannuation: TPD, Critical Illness, Income Protection).
ai_summary: The diagram 'STRUCTURING YOUR INSURANCE THROUGH SUPERANNUATION' outlines a four-step process for structuring Accelerated Protection insurance via superannuation. The steps include selecting one or more insurance plans (Life, TPD, Income Protection), opting for additional benefits, choosing linked plans (TPD, Critical Illness), and selecting linked policies outside superannuation (TPD, Critical Illness, Income Protection), providing a comprehensive framework for tailored insurance coverage.

content: The cost of your Policy depends on a range of factors, including but not limited to the type of cover, your age and sex, whether you smoke, the length of time you have had your Policy and how often you choose to pay your premiums. We may also take your occupation, health, income, personal pastimes, lifestyle, the number or type of Plans you hold across one or more policies, and other factors into account in determining insurance premium amounts. We ask for this information so that the premiums we charge take into account the different levels of risk presented by different customer groups. Sometimes discounts may apply to certain Plans; however, these may not apply for the full term of your Policy. Once we know a little bit about you and the cover you require, we can provide you with an indicative quote for your premium. The quoted premium may change once we have all the information we require to complete our Underwriting assessment. All premiums are payable in advance, by the due date shown in your Policy Schedule. We will inform you of the premium payable in subsequent years before each Policy anniversary.
ai_summary: The cost of your insurance policy is influenced by various factors, including coverage type, age, smoking status, policy duration, payment frequency, occupation, health, and lifestyle. Premiums are determined based on the risk profile of different customer groups, and while discounts may be available, they may not last for the entire policy term. An indicative quote can be provided once initial information is gathered, but the final premium may vary after a complete underwriting assessment. Premiums must be paid in advance by the due date specified in your Policy Schedule, with notifications of subsequent year premiums sent before each policy anniversary.

Subheading: 1.3.1 You can choose to pay stepped or level premiums.
content: Stepped premium: If you choose stepped premium, the premium is calculated based on your total Benefit Amount, the length of time you have had your Policy and your age at each Policy anniversary. This means your premium will generally increase at each Policy anniversary. There are a range of other reasons why your stepped premium may increase, including if we change our premium rates. Please see Sections 1.3.2 and 1.3.3 below for more information. Level premium: Level premiums are not fixed. They can change. If you choose level premiums, the premium is based on your age at the Plan start date. Where you choose to increase your cover or the Inflation Protection benefit applies, the premium rates used to calculate premiums for the increased portion will be based on the Life Insured’s age at that time. There are a range of other reasons why your level premium may increase, including if we change our premium rates. Please see Sections 1.3.2 and 1.3.3 below for more information. Where level premium ‘to age 65’ is shown in your Policy Schedule, premiums will change to stepped premiums on the Policy anniversary before the Life Insured’s 65th birthday. Where level premium ‘to age 70’ is shown in your Policy Schedule, premiums will change to stepped premiums on the Policy anniversary before the Life Insured’s 70th birthday.
ai_summary: In this section, you can choose between stepped or level premiums for your insurance policy. Stepped premiums increase annually based on your total Benefit Amount, policy duration, and age, while level premiums, which are initially based on your age at the policy start date, can also change over time due to various factors. Notably, if you select level premiums 'to age 65' or 'to age 70', they will convert to stepped premiums before the Life Insured's 65th or 70th birthday, respectively. For further details on potential premium increases, refer to Sections 1.3.2 and 1.3.3.

content: For both stepped and level premium, your premiums and the amount you pay will change if: • we change our premium rates or Policy fee (refer to Section 1.3.3 for details); • you vary your Policy, for example when you add or remove a Plan or benefit option; • there is a change in your Benefit Amount, for example when your Benefit Amount increases (including through the Inflation Protection Benefit and Guaranteed Future Insurability Benefit); • a discount no longer applies or changes because you varied your Policy, or another policy held with us; or • government duties or charges change. Premiums for your Policy may change if there are any variations to other Accelerated Protection Plans or Policies you hold or have cover under. This includes, but is not limited to, the following variations – increases or decreases in sums insured, addition or cancellation (including due to non-payment of premium) of other Plans or Policies. When determining premiums, we take into account a number of factors which may include the number or type of Policies or Plans that you hold or have cover under.
ai_summary: Premiums for both stepped and level policies may change due to several factors, including adjustments in premium rates or policy fees, modifications to your coverage (such as adding or removing plans), changes in benefit amounts, the application or removal of discounts, and fluctuations in government duties or charges. Additionally, variations in other Accelerated Protection Plans or Policies you hold, such as changes in sums insured or policy cancellations, can also impact your premiums. These adjustments are influenced by various factors, including the number and type of policies you maintain.

Subheading: 1.3.3 We can change our premium rates
content: If your premiums change there may be options available to help you manage the cost of your cover, please speak to us or a financial adviser for assistance. The cost of your cover is not guaranteed to remain the same each year. It can change for both stepped and level premium cover. In the past we have changed the premium rates used to calculate the cost of cover and Policy fees, including changing the premium rates we use to determine level premiums. We can change our Policy fees or the premium rates we use to determine your premium. If we do this, the cost of your cover will change. However, the premium rates we use to determine your premiums are guaranteed not to change before the first Policy anniversary. Decisions to change premium rates or Policy fees do not occur because of changes to an individual customer’s own circumstances, but rather are determined in relation to the group of customers that we insure. We will act reasonably when making decisions to change our premium rates or Policy fees and will only make changes to the extent reasonably necessary to protect our legitimate business interests. Our premiums and Policy fees are determined so that the total premium and Policy fees for our group of insured customers is enough to cover our expected future claims costs, meeting our associated costs of doing business and margins in providing cover to you. We review associated factors on an ongoing basis which may include, but are by no means limited to, our assessment of regulatory or legislative requirements, our operating costs or the commercial environment. These are only some examples of factors that we may consider and others may apply. The outcome of any premium review performed by us may result in a change to the premium rates and Policy fees we charge you. If we change the premium rates or Policy fees, you will be advised of the change to your premiums or Policy fees at least 30 days before the change takes effect. If your premiums increase, you will always have the option to reduce the premium by reducing your cover, subject to any minimum premiums or sum insured applicable to your Policy. You will also always have the right to cancel your cover, at any time and for any reason, including a premium increase. There may be other options available to help you manage the cost of your cover. Please speak to us or a financial adviser for assistance.
ai_summary: Premium rates for your insurance coverage may change annually, impacting both stepped and level premium options. While the rates are guaranteed not to change before the first policy anniversary, any adjustments will be communicated at least 30 days prior to implementation. Changes are based on group assessments rather than individual circumstances, and you can manage costs by reducing coverage or canceling your policy at any time. For assistance in navigating these changes and exploring options to manage costs, it is recommended to consult with the insurer or a financial adviser.

content: Your Policy cannot be singled out for a change in how premium is charged because of an adverse change in the health or circumstances of the Life Insured after the Policy start date. We may pay commission or other remuneration (such as referral fees) to your financial adviser or other distributors of the Accelerated Protection product. Any amounts paid are factored into the cost of the product. Your financial adviser or the distributor will provide details of the payments they will receive from us in the Financial Services Guide and, if applicable statement of advice that they will give to you. In general, these amounts will be calculated by reference to your premium and will be subject to commission caps imposed by law.
ai_summary: Your policy's premium cannot be adjusted due to adverse changes in the health of the Life Insured after the policy's inception. Commissions or remuneration, such as referral fees, may be paid to financial advisers or distributors of the Accelerated Protection product, which are included in the overall product cost. Details of these payments will be provided in the Financial Services Guide and any applicable statement of advice, and such amounts are typically based on your premium, adhering to legal commission caps.

content:
The Policy fee is included as part of each premium instalment. The Policy fee will be increased on each Policy anniversary by the greater of the Indexation Factor or three percent. The amount of the Policy fee depends on which premium frequency option is selected: 

| Premium frequency | Per instalment | Annual equivalent |
|---|---|---|
| Yearly | $88.00 | $88.00 |
| Half-Yearly | $44.00 | $88.00 |
| Quarterly | $24.00 | $96.00 |
| Monthly | $8.00 | $96.00 |
ai_summary: The Policy fee is incorporated into each premium installment and increases annually by the greater of the Indexation Factor or three percent. The fee varies based on the selected premium frequency, with yearly payments set at $88, half-yearly at $44 (totaling $88 annually), quarterly at $24 (totaling $96 annually), and monthly at $8 (also totaling $96 annually).

content:
Payment method options: 
• Direct debit 
• Credit card (MasterCard or Visa) 
• Rollover when structured through TAL Super (annual payments only) 
• Employer contribution through SuperStream 
• BPAY® 
• From a retail superannuation account or investment account that we have an agreement with 

Payment frequency options: 
• Monthly (not available if paying by BPAY) 
• Quarterly 
• Half yearly* 
• Annually* 

*premium frequency discount may apply
ai_summary: The document outlines various payment methods for insurance premiums, including direct debit, credit card (MasterCard or Visa), BPAY®, and employer contributions via SuperStream, among others. Premiums can be paid monthly (excluding BPAY), quarterly, half-yearly, or annually, with potential discounts available for certain payment frequencies.

content:
Life Insurance only applies if indicated in the Policy Schedule.
A benefit under Life Insurance will only be paid if death or Terminal Illness occurs after the Plan start date and before the Plan end date.
When we refer to a benefit payment, the statement is made on the basis that the benefit referred to is payable under the terms and conditions of the Policy. We will not pay a benefit if an exclusion applies. You must also satisfy our claim requirements, explained in Section 3.
ai_summary: Life Insurance coverage is contingent upon its inclusion in the Policy Schedule and is payable only if death or Terminal Illness occurs between the Plan start and end dates. Benefit payments are subject to the Policy's terms and conditions, and exclusions may apply; claimants must also meet the specified claim requirements outlined in Section 3.

content:
Death Benefit
The Benefit Amount is payable when the Life Insured dies.
ai_summary: The Death Benefit provides a specified Benefit Amount to the designated beneficiaries upon the death of the Life Insured, ensuring financial support in the event of the insured individual's passing.

content:
Terminal Illness Benefit
The Benefit Amount is payable when the Life Insured is diagnosed as Terminally Ill.
If the Terminal Illness Benefit is paid, we will cancel any Attached or Linked Plans.
ai_summary: The Terminal Illness Benefit provides a payout when the Life Insured is diagnosed with a terminal illness, resulting in the cancellation of any Attached or Linked Plans upon payment of this benefit.

content:
Advanced Payment Benefit
The Advanced Payment Benefit is an advance payment of 10% of the Benefit Amount, up to a maximum of $25,000. This benefit will be paid when the death certificate or a medical certificate confirming death of the Life Insured is provided to us.
In the first three years from the Plan start date, the Advanced Payment Benefit will only be paid if the Life Insured’s death resulted from an Accident. After the first three years, the Advanced Payment Benefit will apply for all causes of death unless the cause of death is excluded.
Payment of the Advanced Payment Benefit does not mean any admission or acceptance of any claim or liability regarding current or future payments under Life Insurance.
If we pay the Advanced Payment Benefit and our assessment of the claim determines that the Death Benefit will not be paid due to breach of the duty to take reasonable care not to make a misrepresentation, we will require the Advanced Payment Benefit to be repaid to us.
If the Advanced Payment Benefit is paid, it will reduce the Benefit Amount by the amount paid under the Advanced Payment Benefit.
ai_summary: The Advanced Payment Benefit allows for an advance payment of 10% of the Benefit Amount, up to $25,000, upon submission of a death certificate. Within the first three years of the policy, this benefit is only available if the Life Insured's death is due to an accident; after this period, it applies to all causes of death, barring exclusions. Payment of this benefit does not imply acceptance of liability for the overall claim, and if it is later determined that the Death Benefit is not payable due to misrepresentation, the amount advanced must be repaid, reducing the total Benefit Amount accordingly.

content: If the Life Insured dies outside Australia, we will increase the maximum amount payable under the Advanced Payment Benefit to 10% of the Benefit Amount up to a maximum of $35,000. This benefit will be paid when the death certificate or a certified medical certificate by a Medical Practitioner, confirming death of the Life Insured outside of Australia is provided to us. All other terms and conditions of the Advanced Payment Benefit apply to the Repatriation Benefit.
ai_summary: The Repatriation Benefit under the Life Insurance policy provides that if the Life Insured dies outside Australia, the maximum amount payable under the Advanced Payment Benefit is increased to 10% of the Benefit Amount, capped at $35,000. Payment is contingent upon the submission of a death certificate or a certified medical certificate from a Medical Practitioner confirming the death outside Australia, while all other terms and conditions of the Advanced Payment Benefit remain applicable.

content:
No payments will be made under Life Insurance, and any included or optional benefits (if applicable), if the claim arises directly or indirectly because of an intentional, self-inflicted act by the Life Insured:
* within 13 months after the Plan start date;
* within 13 months after the date of any increase applied for; but only in respect of the increase amount; and
* within 13 months after the most recent date we agreed to reinstate either the Plan or Policy.
We will waive the above exclusion if you had death cover on the Life Insured that was in force for at least 13 consecutive months immediately before the Plan start date (without the death cover being cancelled and/or reinstated) with TAL or another insurer, and you have replaced the death cover with Life Insurance under this Policy. The waiver will only apply up to the level of death cover you had with TAL or the other insurer.
If the Life Insurance Plan is reinstated, the exclusion above will recommence from the date of reinstatement.
Any cover bought back under the Death Buy-Back Option or Death Buy-Back Benefit will be issued subject to the limitations and conditions, exclusions and loadings which were applicable to the original Policy. If Accelerated Protection is no longer available when the Death Buy-Back Option or Death Buy-Back Benefit is exercised, we will issue a death cover comparable to Accelerated Protection Life Insurance. Any additional benefits under the new death cover which are not available with Accelerated Protection Life Insurance will not apply.
ai_summary: Life Insurance claims will not be paid if they result from intentional self-inflicted acts within 13 months of the Plan start date, any increase in coverage, or reinstatement of the policy. However, this exclusion can be waived if the insured had continuous death cover for at least 13 months prior to the Plan start date with TAL or another insurer, provided it is replaced with Life Insurance under this Policy. If the Plan is reinstated, the exclusion restarts from that date. Additionally, any cover obtained through the Death Buy-Back Option will adhere to the original policy's limitations and conditions, and if Accelerated Protection is unavailable, a comparable death cover will be issued without additional benefits.

Life Insurance coverage under the Plan terminates on the earliest of several conditions: the policy anniversary before the Life Insured's 100th birthday, the policy anniversary before the 75th birthday if through TAL Super or a retail superannuation fund (with an option to transfer ownership), cancellation by the Policy Owner, non-payment of premiums, cancellation due to misrepresentation or fraud, the death of the Life Insured, or when the full Benefit Amount is paid. If structured through a retail superannuation fund, coverage ends upon ceasing membership, but the Policy can be continued within 60 days without further medical or financial requirements, retaining any special conditions from the original Plan.

content:
TPD Insurance only applies if indicated in the Policy Schedule. The TPD definition and any applicable options are shown in the Policy Schedule.
A benefit under TPD Insurance will only be paid if the conditions and requirements for a claimable event are met after the Plan start date and before the Plan end date.
When we refer to a benefit payment, the statement is made on the basis that the benefit referred to is payable under the terms and conditions of the Policy. You must also satisfy our claim requirements, explained in Section 3.
ai_summary: TPD Insurance is applicable only if specified in the Policy Schedule, which outlines the definition and options related to TPD. A benefit will be paid only if the claimable event occurs between the Plan start and end dates, and all conditions, terms, and claim requirements outlined in the Policy and Section 3 are satisfied.

content:
TPD Benefit
The TPD Benefit is payable if the Life Insured becomes Totally and Permanently Disabled. The applicable TPD definition is shown in the Policy Schedule.
The following TPD definitions are available:
• ‘Any Occupation’;
• ‘Own Occupation’ (not available when structured through superannuation); or
• ‘Activities of Daily Living (ADL)’.
If the definition requires that the Life Insured has not been working (whether in their Own Occupation or any occupation, as applicable) for three consecutive months, the Benefit Amount payable will be the TPD Insurance Benefit Amount at the end of the three-month period. If the TPD Insurance Plan expires during the three-month period, the TPD Benefit payable will be the TPD Insurance Benefit Amount immediately before the Plan end date.
For other definitions of Total and Permanent Disability, the Benefit Amount payable will be the TPD Insurance Benefit Amount on the date the Life Insured first meets the applicable definition of Total and Permanent Disability.
If the TPD Benefit is paid, it will reduce the Benefit Amount of any Attached and/or Linked Plans by the amount paid.
ai_summary: The Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) Benefit is payable if the Life Insured becomes Totally and Permanently Disabled, with definitions including 'Any Occupation,' 'Own Occupation,' and 'Activities of Daily Living (ADL).' If the Life Insured has not been working for three consecutive months, the benefit amount is determined at that time, and if the TPD Insurance Plan expires during this period, the benefit amount is based on the amount just before expiration. Payment of the TPD Benefit will also reduce the benefit amounts of any Attached or Linked Plans by the same amount.

content:
Advanced Payment Benefit
Not available when structured through superannuation.
We will pay 25% of the Benefit Amount, up to a maximum of $500,000 if the Life Insured suffers one of the following:
• Loss of use of a Single Limb (permanent); or
• Loss of Sight in One Eye (permanent).
This is only payable once and the TPD Insurance Benefit Amount and the Benefit Amount under any Attached or Linked Plan, will be reduced by the amount paid under the Advanced Payment Benefit.
ai_summary: The Advanced Payment Benefit under TPD Insurance provides a one-time payment of 25% of the Benefit Amount, up to $500,000, if the Life Insured experiences permanent loss of use of a single limb or permanent loss of sight in one eye. This benefit is not available when the insurance is structured through superannuation and will reduce both the TPD Insurance Benefit Amount and any benefits under Attached or Linked Plans by the amount paid.

content:
The options listed below only apply if indicated in your Policy Schedule.
Death Buy-Back Option
Only available if TPD Insurance is Linked or Attached to Life Insurance.
If we pay 100% of the TPD Insurance Benefit Amount, TPD Insurance will end. When this occurs, under the Death Buy-Back Option, you can buy-back Life Insurance on the Life Insured.
The amount of cover you may repurchase is the amount of the TPD Insurance Benefit Amount paid. The Death Buy-Back Option can be exercised without having to provide evidence of health, occupation, income or pastimes, or any other Underwriting information.
You must notify us in writing of your intention to exercise the Death Buy-Back Option. Notification must occur during the 30 days following the 12-month anniversary of the date we were notified formally of a claim in accordance with our claim requirements (see Section 3), and in relation to a claim which was subsequently paid. Any further requirements must be submitted to us within 30 days of the date we received your notification, or the Death Buy-Back Option will expire.
If payment of the claim occurs more than 12 months after the formal notification was made to us, buy-back will be available for 30 days from the date of payment. If you fail to exercise the Death Buy-Back during this 30-day period, the Death Buy-Back Option will expire.
The Death Buy-Back Option will expire if not exercised before the Policy anniversary before the Life Insured’s 65th birthday.
The premium for the repurchased Life Insurance will be calculated using our standard premium rates for the age of the Life Insured at the time the option is exercised and will take into account any extra premiums charged and special provisions that apply to the Life Insurance Plan for the Life Insured.
The repurchased Life Insurance will not be eligible for the following benefits and options:
• Inflation Protection Benefit;
• Guaranteed Future Insurability Benefit;
• Premium Relief Option; or
• Business Insurance Option (if applicable).
The Death Buy-Back Option does not apply where ‘Double TPD’ or ‘Double Critical Illness’ is shown in your Policy Schedule.
ai_summary: The Death Buy-Back Option allows policyholders to repurchase Life Insurance equal to the TPD Insurance Benefit Amount paid, provided TPD Insurance is linked to Life Insurance. This option must be exercised within 30 days following the 12-month anniversary of a claim notification, or within 30 days of payment if the claim is delayed. The option expires before the Life Insured's 65th birthday and does not apply if 'Double TPD' or 'Double Critical Illness' is indicated in the Policy Schedule. Repurchased Life Insurance will be subject to standard premium rates and will exclude certain benefits such as Inflation Protection and Guaranteed Future Insurability.

content:
Double TPD Option
Only available if TPD Insurance is Attached or Linked to Life Insurance.
If ‘Double TPD’ is indicated in your Policy Schedule, and 100% of the TPD Insurance Benefit Amount becomes payable:
• the Life Insurance Benefit Amount will not be reduced;
• future premiums due in respect of that part of the Life Insurance Benefit Amount equal to the TPD Insurance Benefit Amount paid will be waived;
• the Life Insurance Benefit Amount equal to the TPD Insurance Benefit Amount paid will continue until the Life Insurance Plan end date; and
• in the event cover is transferred to non-superannuation ownership, future premiums due in respect of that part of the Life Insurance Benefit Amount equal to the TPD Insurance Benefit Amount paid will be waived.
The portion of Life Insurance where the premiums are waived will not be eligible for the following benefits and options:
• Inflation Protection Benefit;
• Guaranteed Future Insurability Benefit;
• Premium Relief Option; or
• Business Insurance Option (if applicable).
This option will expire on the Policy anniversary before the Life Insured’s 65th birthday.
Superlink TPD
Superlink TPD allows you to structure TPD Insurance as follows:
• TPD ‘Any Occupation’ definition structured through superannuation; and
• TPD ‘Own Occupation’ definition structured outside superannuation.
Two Policies will be issued, one of which will be issued to the trustee of a superannuation fund, and the other will be issued outside of superannuation. The policies will be Linked and the following additional conditions apply:
• the TPD Insurance Benefit Amount, any optional benefits selected, and any loadings or exclusions (if applicable) of each Policy must always be the same;
• if TPD Insurance is reduced or increased under one Policy, TPD Insurance on the other Policy will be reduced or increased (as applicable) at the same time;
• if the Policy structured through superannuation is cancelled (not because of a claim payment), the Policy structured outside superannuation will also be cancelled unless you notify us in writing to retain the Plan structured outside superannuation before cancellation;
• if TPD Insurance structured outside superannuation is cancelled, cover will continue under the Policy structured through superannuation, and Superlink TPD will no longer apply; and
• the maximum benefits payable under both Policies will never exceed that which would be payable under a single TPD Policy.
Claims will first be assessed using the ‘Any Occupation’ definition under TPD Insurance Plan structured through superannuation and the SIS definition of Permanent Incapacity. If these definitions are satisfied the Benefit Amount will be paid to the trustee. If these definitions are not satisfied, the claim will be assessed using the ‘Own Occupation’ definition under the TPD Insurance Plan structured outside superannuation and any Benefit Amount payable will be paid to the Policy Owner.
The Policy Schedules will indicate if Superlink TPD applies.
ai_summary: The Double TPD Option, available only with linked Life Insurance, ensures that upon full TPD Insurance payout, the Life Insurance Benefit remains intact, future premiums for the equivalent amount are waived, and coverage continues until the policy's end date. However, this portion will not qualify for certain benefits like Inflation Protection or Premium Relief. The Superlink TPD allows structuring TPD Insurance with 'Any Occupation' through superannuation and 'Own Occupation' outside it, requiring both policies to maintain identical terms and conditions. Claims are assessed first under the superannuation policy's definitions; if unmet, the outside policy's definitions apply, with a maximum payout equal to that of a single TPD Policy.

content:
No payment will be made under TPD Insurance and any included or optional benefits (if applicable) if the claim arises directly or indirectly because of an intentional, self-inflicted act by the Life Insured.
If TPD Insurance is Attached or Linked to Life Insurance, the TPD Benefit will not be paid if you are also eligible for the Terminal Illness Benefit under Life Insurance.
If TPD Insurance is not Attached or Linked to Life Insurance, no payment will be made under TPD Insurance unless the Life Insured survives the Sickness or Injury which resulted in Total and Permanent Disability, for at least 14 days.
ai_summary: Payments under TPD Insurance will not be made for claims resulting from intentional self-inflicted acts by the Life Insured. If TPD Insurance is linked to Life Insurance, the TPD Benefit is excluded if the Life Insured qualifies for the Terminal Illness Benefit. Additionally, if TPD Insurance is not linked to Life Insurance, the Life Insured must survive the Sickness or Injury causing Total and Permanent Disability for a minimum of 14 days to be eligible for payment.

TPD Insurance terminates under several conditions, including reaching the policy anniversary before the insured's 65th birthday, cancellation requests, non-payment of premiums, misrepresentation or fraudulent claims, the death of the insured, or when the full benefit amount is paid. If TPD Insurance is linked to Life or Critical Illness Insurance, its cancellation will also affect TPD Insurance unless a written request is made to retain it as a standalone plan. Premium rates may change if any linked plans are canceled, and if structured through a retail superannuation fund, TPD Insurance ends upon ceasing membership, with a 60-day window to continue the plan without further medical or financial requirements.

content:
Critical Illness Insurance only applies if indicated in the Policy Schedule. Critical Illness Insurance is available as 'Standard' or 'Premier'. The type of Critical Illness Insurance and any applicable options is stated in your Policy Schedule. Critical Illness Insurance cannot be structured through superannuation.
A benefit under Critical Illness Insurance will only be paid if the conditions and requirements for a claimable event are met after the Plan start date but before the Plan end date and the Life Insured suffers a specified serious event as described in the sections below. We require confirmation of diagnosis by a Medical Practitioner and the specified severity threshold criteria to be met, for a benefit to be payable. The severity threshold criteria are defined for each event in Section 9.
For many specified serious events this means the condition will be required to progress beyond a diagnosis, where diagnosis means the process of a Medical Practitioner determining which Sickness or Injury explains an individual’s symptoms. You must also satisfy our claim requirements in Section 3 of this PDS.
When we refer to a benefit payment, the statement is made on the basis that the benefit referred to is payable under the terms and conditions of the Policy.
ai_summary: Critical Illness Insurance is applicable only if specified in the Policy Schedule and is offered in 'Standard' or 'Premier' options. Benefits are payable for specified serious events occurring between the Plan start and end dates, contingent upon meeting claim requirements, including confirmation of diagnosis by a Medical Practitioner and adherence to severity threshold criteria outlined in Section 9. The condition must progress beyond mere diagnosis for a claim to be valid, and all claims must also satisfy the requirements detailed in Section 3 of the PDS.

content:
The following benefits, in addition to the benefits set out in Section 2.4, are included in Critical Illness Insurance Standard and Premier, unless otherwise indicated.
Critical Illness Benefit
The Benefit Amount is payable if the Life Insured suffers a Critical Illness Event listed in the table below.
If the Life Insured suffers more than one Critical Illness Event, the Benefit Amount is only payable for the first occurring Critical Illness Event, unless the first to occur is Angioplasty. If Angioplasty occurs and a claim is paid, the remaining Benefit Amount will be the basis used to determine payment in accordance with the Critical Illness Insurance terms and conditions if the Life Insured suffers another Critical Illness Event.
More than one payment can be made for Angioplasty, as long as the first Angioplasty procedure ever undergone by the Life Insured occurred after the Plan start date.
The following conditions apply to Critical Illness Insurance Standard Plan for Angioplasty:
• each Angioplasty procedure occurring at least six months after the previous Angioplasty; and
• a maximum of three payments.
If the Critical Illness Benefit is paid, it will reduce the Critical Illness Insurance Benefit Amount and the Benefit Amount of any Attached and/or Linked Plans, by the amount paid.
ai_summary: Critical Illness Insurance Standard and Premier plans provide a Benefit Amount for the first Critical Illness Event suffered by the Life Insured, with the exception of Angioplasty, which allows for multiple payments under specific conditions. For Angioplasty, benefits can be claimed for procedures occurring at least six months apart, up to a maximum of three payments, provided the first procedure occurs after the Plan start date. Payment of the Critical Illness Benefit reduces the Benefit Amount for the policy and any Attached or Linked Plans.

Subheading: Critical Illness Events applicable to Standard and Premier
content:
Heart conditions:
* Angioplasty¹²
* Angioplasty for Triple Vessel Disease¹
* Aortic Surgery (for specified conditions)
* Cardiomyopathy (permanent)
* Heart Attack (of specified severity)¹
* Heart Valve Surgery¹
* Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery¹
* Open Heart Surgery¹
* Out of Hospital Cardiac Arrest (requiring cardiopulmonary resuscitation)¹
* Idiopathic Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (of specified severity)

Neurological conditions:
* Coma (of specified severity)
* Dementia including Alzheimer's Disease (permanent)
* Encephalitis (resulting in permanent neurological deficit)
* Major Head Trauma (with permanent neurological deficit)
* Meningitis (resulting in significant permanent impairment)
* Multiple Sclerosis (with multiple episodes of neurological deficit and persisting neurological abnormalities)¹
* Muscular Dystrophy
* Paralysis (permanent)
* Parkinson's Disease (permanent)
* Progressive and Debilitating Motor Neurone Disease
* Stroke (resulting in neurological deficit)¹

Permanent conditions:
* Blindness (permanent)
* Deafness (permanent)
* Loss of Independent Existence (permanent)
* Loss of use of Limbs (permanent)
* Loss of Speech (permanent)

Organ disorders:
* Chronic Kidney Failure (undergoing permanent dialysis)
* Chronic Liver Failure (resulting in permanent symptoms)
* Chronic Lung Failure (on permanent oxygen therapy)
* Major Organ Transplant (of specified organs)
* Pneumonectomy
* Severe Burns (covering at least 20% of the body's surface area)

Blood disorders:
* Aplastic Anaemia (requiring treatment)
* Medically-Acquired HIV (contracted from a medical procedure or operation)
* Occupationally-Acquired HIV

Cancer:
* Benign Brain Tumour (resulting in irreversible neurological deficit)¹
* Cancer (of specified criteria)¹
ai_summary: Section 2.3 outlines critical illness events covered under Standard and Premier plans, detailing various heart, neurological, permanent, organ, blood disorders, and cancer conditions. Key heart conditions include severe heart attacks and surgeries, while neurological conditions encompass permanent deficits from strokes and dementia. Permanent conditions covered include blindness and loss of speech, and organ disorders feature chronic failures requiring ongoing treatment. Blood disorders include treatment-requiring aplastic anaemia and medically-acquired HIV. Cancer coverage specifies certain criteria for diagnosis, emphasizing the importance of severity and permanence in determining eligibility for benefits.

content:
* John has taken out Critical Illness Insurance with a Benefit Amount of $1,200,000 and has opted out of the Inflation Protection Benefit.
* Some years later John suffers Paralysis (permanent) and makes a claim on Critical Illness Insurance.
* Since John has met the definition of Paralysis (permanent), he qualifies for the Paralysis Support Benefit.
* He therefore receives his Critical Illness Insurance Benefit Amount of $1,200,000, as well as a Paralysis Support Benefit Amount of $800,000.
* The total amount paid to John from the Critical Illness Benefit and Paralysis Support Benefit has been limited to a maximum of $2,000,000 in aggregate.
ai_summary: John holds a Critical Illness Insurance policy with a benefit amount of $1,200,000 and has opted out of the Inflation Protection Benefit. After suffering from permanent paralysis, he qualifies for the Paralysis Support Benefit and receives the full Critical Illness benefit along with an additional $800,000 support benefit, totaling $2,000,000, which is the maximum aggregate payout allowed under his policy.

content:
Only available when Critical Illness Insurance is Attached or Linked to Life Insurance.

If we pay 100% of the Critical Illness Benefit, Paralysis Support Benefit or TPD Benefit, Critical Illness Insurance will end. When this occurs, under the Death Buy-Back Benefit, you can repurchase Life Insurance on the Life Insured. The amount you can repurchase is the amount of Critical Illness Benefit paid.

The Death Buy-Back Benefit can be exercised without having to provide evidence of health, occupation, income or pastimes, or any other Underwriting information.

You must notify us in writing of your intention to exercise the Death Buy-Back Benefit during the 30 days after the 12 month anniversary of the date we were notified formally of a claim in accordance with our claim requirements (see Section 3) in relation to a claim which was subsequently paid. Any further requirements must be submitted to us within 30 days of the date we received your notification or the Death Buy-Back Benefit will expire.

If payment of the claim occurs more than 12 months after the formal notification was made to us, repurchase will be available for 30 days from the date of payment. If you fail to exercise the Death Buy-Back Benefit during this 30 day period, the Death Buy-Back Benefit will expire.

The Death Buy-Back Benefit will expire if not exercised before the Policy anniversary before the Life Insured's 70th birthday.

The premium for the repurchased Life Insurance will be calculated using our standard premium rates for the age of the Life Insured at the time the option is exercised and will take into account any extra premiums charged and special provisions that apply to the Life Insurance Plan for the Life Insured.

The repurchased Life Insurance will not be eligible for increases under the Inflation Protection Benefit, Guaranteed Future Insurability Benefit, or Business Insurance Option (if applicable).

The Death Buy-Back Benefit does not apply:
* Unless Critical Illness Insurance is Attached or Linked to Life Insurance; or
* When 'Double Critical Illness' or 'Double TPD' is shown in your Policy Schedule.
ai_summary: The Death Buy-Back Benefit allows the repurchase of Life Insurance equal to the Critical Illness Benefit paid, but is only available when Critical Illness Insurance is linked to Life Insurance. This benefit can be exercised without providing additional health information, but must be requested in writing within 30 days after the 12-month anniversary of a claim notification, or within 30 days of claim payment if it exceeds 12 months. The option expires before the policy anniversary preceding the Life Insured's 70th birthday and is subject to standard premium rates based on the Life Insured's age at the time of exercise. Notably, the benefit does not apply if 'Double Critical Illness' or 'Double TPD' is indicated in the Policy Schedule.

content: The following benefits only apply if 'Premier' is shown in your Policy Schedule.
ai_summary: Section 2.3.2 outlines that the benefits listed are exclusively available to policyholders whose Policy Schedule indicates 'Premier.' These benefits are designed to enhance coverage for critical illnesses, providing additional financial support and resources tailored to the needs of those enrolled in the Premier plan.

content:
If the Life Insured suffers an Advancement Benefit Event listed in the table below, the Advancement Benefit will be payable. The amount payable is shown in the following table.

The Advancement Benefit is payable only once for each Event. If the Life Insured is eligible for more than one Critical Illness Event and/or Advancement Benefit Event at the same time, the Events will be treated as occurring consecutively. We will consider the event with the highest amount payable to have taken place first.

The Advancement Benefit will only be paid if the condition or the circumstances leading to the claim first occurs after the Plan start date.

If the Advancement Benefit is paid, it will reduce the Critical Illness Insurance Benefit Amount and the Benefit Amount of any Attached or Linked Plans by the amount paid.
ai_summary: The Advancement Benefit under the Critical Illness Insurance is payable once for each specified event, with the payout amount detailed in a provided table. If multiple events occur, they are treated consecutively, with the highest payout event prioritized. Eligibility for the benefit requires that the event occurs after the plan's start date, and any amount paid will reduce the overall Critical Illness Insurance Benefit Amount and any related plans.

Subheading: Critical Illness Events applicable to Premier:
content:
Organ disorders:
* Severe Diabetes Mellitus (of specified severity)

Blood disorders:
* Occupationally-Acquired Hepatitis B or C³

¹A three-month qualifying period applies. Refer to the 'When we will not pay' Section 2.3.4 for details.
²The amount to be paid is reduced to 25% of the Benefit amount to a maximum of $50,000.
³Only payable under the Needlestick Benefit.
ai_summary: Section 2.3 of the insurance document outlines the Critical Illness Insurance coverage for Premier, specifically detailing applicable critical illness events. Covered conditions include Severe Diabetes Mellitus (of specified severity) under organ disorders and Occupationally-Acquired Hepatitis B or C under blood disorders, with a three-month qualifying period for claims. Additionally, the payout for certain conditions may be reduced to 25% of the benefit amount, capped at $50,000, and specific benefits are only payable under the Needlestick Benefit. For further exclusions, refer to Section 2.3.4.

content:
If the Life Insured suffers Paralysis (permanent), we will pay the Paralysis Support Benefit Amount in addition to the Critical Illness Benefit.

The Paralysis Support Benefit Amount is the additional amount we will pay under the Paralysis Support Benefit to such that the aggregate amount paid under both the Critical Illness Benefit and Paralysis Support Benefit is the lesser of:
* two times the Critical Illness Insurance Benefit Amount; and
* $2,000,000.

If the Paralysis Support Benefit is paid, we will reduce the Benefit Amount of any Attached or Linked Plans by the Critical Illness Insurance Benefit Amount only.
ai_summary: The Paralysis Support Benefit provides an additional payment to the Life Insured if they suffer permanent paralysis, alongside the Critical Illness Benefit. The total payout from both benefits will not exceed the lesser of twice the Critical Illness Insurance Benefit Amount or $2,000,000. Additionally, if the Paralysis Support Benefit is claimed, the Benefit Amount of any Attached or Linked Plans will be reduced by the amount of the Critical Illness Insurance Benefit.

Section 2.3 outlines the Advancement Benefit Events for Critical Illness Insurance, detailing various covered conditions such as heart attacks, strokes, major organ transplants, life-threatening cancers, and neurological disorders. Each condition has specific diagnostic criteria and exclusions, emphasizing that the list is illustrative and not exhaustive; full definitions and coverage details are provided in the Policy Document. Key benefits include financial support upon diagnosis of qualifying illnesses, subject to the terms and conditions of the policy.

content: The Female Critical Illness Benefit will be payable upon the occurrence of a Female Critical Illness Event listed in the table below and only apply if the Life Insured is female. The payment for each event is 20% of the Benefit Amount, up to a maximum of $50,000. Each Female Critical Illness Event can only be paid once. If the Female Critical Illness Benefit is paid, it will reduce the Critical Illness Insurance Benefit Amount and the Benefit Amount of any Attached or Linked Plans by the amount paid.
ai_summary: The Female Critical Illness Benefit provides a payout of 20% of the Benefit Amount, up to a maximum of $50,000, upon the diagnosis of a specified Female Critical Illness Event for female Life Insured individuals. Each event is eligible for a one-time payment, which will subsequently reduce the overall Critical Illness Insurance Benefit Amount and any associated Attached or Linked Plans by the amount disbursed.

The reinstated Critical Illness Insurance premium will be based on the insured's age at the time of repurchase, considering any prior special provisions. The repurchased coverage will match the previously paid benefit amount but will exclude options like Death Buy-Back and Inflation Protection. Claims for new critical illnesses will be honored only if they arise after repurchase and are not related to previously covered conditions. Specific exclusions apply, particularly for heart conditions and strokes if they were previously claimed. The reinstatement option is unavailable if a Total Permanent Disability or Terminal Illness Benefit has been paid.

content:
2.3.4 When we will not pay
No payments will be made under any included or optional benefits (if applicable) if the claim arises directly or indirectly because of an intentional, self-inflicted act by the Life Insured.
• Critical Illness Insurance is Attached or Linked to Life Insurance, the Critical Illness Benefit will not be paid if you are also eligible for the Terminal Illness Benefit under Life Insurance.
• Critical Illness Insurance is not Attached or Linked to Life Insurance, no benefits will be paid under Critical Illness Insurance unless the Life Insured survives the Critical Illness Event for at least 14 days.
ai_summary: Payments under Critical Illness Insurance will not be made for claims resulting from intentional self-inflicted acts by the Life Insured. If the Critical Illness Insurance is linked to Life Insurance, benefits will not be paid if the Life Insured qualifies for the Terminal Illness Benefit; if not linked, the Life Insured must survive the Critical Illness Event for at least 14 days to receive benefits.

content:
Qualifying period
No payment will be made if a claim arises directly or indirectly because of any one of the Critical Illness Events listed in the table below if the condition occurred or was diagnosed, or the signs or symptoms leading to the diagnosis became apparent to the Life Insured or would have become apparent to a reasonable person in the position of the Life Insured:
• within three months after the Plan start date¹;
• within three months after the date of any approved increase applied for, but only in respect of the increase portion¹; or
• within three months after the most recent date we agreed to reinstate the Plan or Policy.
¹ If Interim Rollover Cover Benefit applies, the qualifying period will start when Interim Rollover Cover Benefit starts. If the Plan has not started at the expiration of 30 days from the Interim Rollover Cover Benefit start date due to non-payment, the qualifying period will reset to the Plan start date.
Critical Illness Events where qualifying period applies
• Angioplasty
• Angioplasty for Triple Vessel Disease
• Benign Brain Tumour (resulting in irreversible neurological deficit)
• Carcinoma In Situ (of specified site)
• Cancer (of specified criteria)
• Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery
• Diagnosed Benign Brain Tumour (of specified severity)
• Early Stage Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia
• Early Stage Skin Melanoma (excluding melanoma in situ)
• Early Stage Prostate Cancer
• Heart Attack (of specified severity)
• Heart Valve Surgery
• Multiple Sclerosis (with episodes of neurological deficit and persisting neurological abnormalities)
• Open Heart Surgery
• Out of Hospital Cardiac Arrest (requiring cardiopulmonary resuscitation)
• Stroke (resulting in neurological deficit)
• Type 1 Diabetes diagnosed after age 30
We will waive this three-month period if:
• you were insured with us or another insurer for the same events immediately before your cover starts; and
• you transferred your cover after any similar three month period.
ai_summary: The qualifying period for Critical Illness Insurance stipulates that no claims will be paid for specified conditions if they arise within three months of the Plan start date, any approved increase, or the most recent reinstatement date. This period applies to various Critical Illness Events, including heart attacks, strokes, and certain cancers. However, the three-month waiting period may be waived if the insured had prior coverage for the same events with another insurer and transferred their policy without a lapse in coverage.

Critical Illness Insurance ends at the earlier of the policy anniversary before the Life Insured's 70th birthday, upon written cancellation by the Policy Owner, non-payment of premiums, misrepresentation or fraud, the Life Insured's death, or when the full Benefit Amount is paid. If linked to Life Insurance, cancellation of the latter also cancels Critical Illness Insurance unless specified otherwise in writing. Additionally, if the Critical Illness Insurance is attached to Life Insurance, eligibility for the Terminal Illness Benefit may affect claims. Premium rates will adjust based on the Life Insured's age if any linked plans are retained or canceled, and changes increasing liability will necessitate full underwriting.

Section_Title: 2.4 Additional Benefits and Options applicable to Life, TPD and Critical Illness Insurance
content: The following benefits and options are only available to Life Insurance, TPD Insurance and Critical Illness Insurance. Please note that some benefits are not included when the Plan is structured through superannuation.
ai_summary: Section 2.4 outlines additional benefits and options available exclusively for Life Insurance, Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) Insurance, and Critical Illness Insurance, emphasizing that certain benefits may be excluded if the plan is set up through superannuation. It is essential for policyholders to review the specific terms and conditions related to these benefits to understand their applicability and any limitations that may arise from superannuation structuring.

Section_Title: 2.4 Additional Benefits and Options applicable to Life, TPD and Critical Illness Insurance
content:
We will increase the Benefit Amount by the greater of the Indexation Factor and five per cent at each Policy anniversary unless:
• you tell us not to apply the Inflation Protection Benefit to your Plan;
• the premiums are being waived under the Premium Relief Option; or
• if Life Insurance resulted from exercising the Death Buy-Back Option, Double TPD Option, Death Buy-Back Benefit or Double Critical Illness Option.
For information on how this will impact your premium, please refer to Section 1.3.
The Inflation Protection Benefit doesn’t apply to Child’s Critical Illness Benefit and Child’s Critical Illness Insurance.
ai_summary: The Inflation Protection Benefit automatically increases the Benefit Amount by the greater of the Indexation Factor or five percent at each Policy anniversary, unless the policyholder opts out, is under the Premium Relief Option, or if the Life Insurance is linked to specific options like the Death Buy-Back or Double TPD. This benefit does not apply to Child’s Critical Illness Insurance or Benefit, and details on its impact on premiums can be found in Section 1.3.

Section_Title: 2.4 Additional Benefits and Options applicable to Life, TPD and Critical Illness Insurance
content:
The Premium Freeze Benefit can only be activated if we are charging premiums on a stepped premium basis and the Life Insured is older than age 30. You may elect to activate the Premium Freeze Benefit by notifying us in writing.
If you choose to exercise the Premium Freeze Benefit, your premium will remain unchanged, but the Benefit Amount will reduce on a yearly basis at each Policy anniversary. This is because insurance generally becomes more expensive as you get older. The reduction of the Benefit Amount will be calculated based on your age and the premium rate applicable to you.
If you notify us that you wish to apply the Premium Freeze Benefit, the Inflation Protection Benefit will not apply. If you notify us that the Premium Freeze Benefit is to cease within three years of it starting, the Inflation Protection Benefit will then recommence but only if it was applicable before the Premium Freeze Benefit being activated.
ai_summary: The Premium Freeze Benefit allows policyholders aged over 30 with stepped premiums to maintain their premium amount by notifying the insurer in writing. However, this benefit results in a yearly reduction of the Benefit Amount at each policy anniversary, reflecting the increasing cost of insurance with age. If activated, the Inflation Protection Benefit will be suspended, but can resume if the Premium Freeze Benefit is terminated within three years, provided it was applicable prior to activation.

Section_Title: 2.4 Additional Benefits and Options applicable to Life, TPD and Critical Illness Insurance
content:
You can apply to increase your Benefit Amount under the Guaranteed Future Insurability Benefit for Life Insurance, TPD Insurance and Critical Illness Insurance without providing evidence of your health or pastimes when one of the following personal or business events occur:
Personal events
• The birth of a child where the Life Insured is the parent.
• A dependent child of the Life Insured starting primary or secondary school.
• Marriage of the Life Insured.
• Divorce of the Life Insured.
• The Life Insured’s base salary increases by at least $10,000 (this only applies if you’re an Employee).
• The Life Insured completes a post graduate degree.
• The Life Insured taking out a new mortgage or increasing the existing mortgage.
• The Life Insured becoming a Carer.
• The Life Insured has a change in tax dependency status as a result of the Life Insured ceasing to have any tax dependents as defined by current law.
Business events
• An increase in the Life Insured’s value to the business, where the Life Insured is a key person in that business.
• An increase in the Life Insured’s financial interest in the business, whether as a partner, shareholder or unit holder, and the Policy forms part of a buy-sell, share purchase or business succession agreement.
• An increase in the loan liability of the business for which the Life Insured is the primary guarantor.
ai_summary: The Guaranteed Future Insurability Benefit allows the Life Insured to increase their Benefit Amount for Life, TPD, and Critical Illness Insurance without health evidence following specific personal events (e.g., marriage, childbirth, salary increase) or business events (e.g., increased value or financial interest in a business). This benefit facilitates coverage adjustments in response to significant life changes, ensuring that the insurance remains aligned with the insured's evolving circumstances.

Section_Title: 2.4 Additional Benefits and Options applicable to Life, TPD and Critical Illness Insurance
content:
The Guaranteed Future Insurability Benefit is limited by the following:
• You must apply in writing within 30 days from when the event (described in the table above) first occurred or within 30 days before the next Policy anniversary following the event.
• You can only exercise the Guaranteed Future Insurability Benefit once in any 12-month period.
• You must provide evidence which (in our reasonable opinion) establishes that the event has occurred.
• The event occurring while the Policy is in-force.
• The event occurred when the Life Insured is under age 55.
ai_summary: The Guaranteed Future Insurability Benefit allows policyholders to apply for additional coverage under specific conditions: applications must be submitted in writing within 30 days of a qualifying event or before the next policy anniversary, can only be exercised once every 12 months, and require evidence of the event's occurrence while the policy is active and the insured is under 55 years old.

Section_Title: 2.4 Additional Benefits and Options applicable to Life, TPD and Critical Illness Insurance
content:
The maximum amount that you can apply for to increase the Benefit Amount under the Guaranteed Future Insurability Benefit is the lesser of:
• 25% of the Benefit Amount at the Plan start date of the corresponding Plan which you are applying for an increase;
• the amount of mortgage or business loan taken out or increased (if applicable);
• five times the amount of the base salary increase (if applicable); and
• $200,000.
If TPD Insurance and/or Critical Illness Insurance is Attached to Life Insurance, the Benefit Amount for TPD Insurance and/or Critical Illness Insurance after the increase under the Guaranteed Future Insurability Benefit cannot exceed the Life Insurance Benefit Amount.
The total maximum amount for all increases under the Guaranteed Future Insurability Benefit cannot exceed the lesser of:
• the Benefit Amount at the Plan start date; or
• $1,000,000.
If the Benefit Amount has been increased using the Guaranteed Future Insurability Benefit, the total cover (including cover with TAL and any other organisation) must not exceed:
• $3,000,000 for Life Insurance;
• $3,000,000 for TPD Insurance; and
• $2,000,000 for Critical Illness Insurance.
During the first six months after exercising the Guaranteed Future Insurability Benefit, the increased portion of the Benefit Amount will only be paid in the event of the Life Insured suffering:
• Accidental death;
• TPD caused by Accident; or
• any of the listed Critical Illness Events caused by Accident.
ai_summary: The Guaranteed Future Insurability Benefit allows policyholders to increase their Benefit Amount by the lesser of 25% of the initial Benefit Amount, the amount of any mortgage or business loan increase, five times the base salary increase, or $200,000, with total increases capped at the lesser of the initial Benefit Amount or $1,000,000. If TPD and/or Critical Illness Insurance is attached to Life Insurance, their increased amounts cannot exceed the Life Insurance Benefit Amount. Additionally, total coverage limits are set at $3,000,000 for Life and TPD Insurance and $2,000,000 for Critical Illness Insurance. Notably, any increase will only be payable for accidental death, TPD due to accident, or

Section_Title: 2.4 Additional Benefits and Options applicable to Life, TPD and Critical Illness Insurance
ai_summary: The Guaranteed Future Insurability Benefit cannot be exercised under specific conditions, including when premiums are waived under the Premium Relief Option, if exclusions or premium increases due to medical history apply, or if coverage results from certain buy-back options or reinstatement options. Additionally, it is not available if the applicant did not undergo underwriting or is entitled to claim under any life insurance policy with TAL or another insurer.

Section_Title: 2.4 Additional Benefits and Options applicable to Life, TPD and Critical Illness Insurance
content:
This benefit is not available when structured through superannuation.
If we pay 100% of the Benefit Amount under Life Insurance, Critical Illness Insurance or TPD Insurance, we will reimburse the costs associated with the preparation of a financial plan by a financial adviser for the person(s) to whom we paid 100% of the Benefit Amount, or to their Immediate Family Member.
The following conditions apply to the Financial Planning Benefit:
• The maximum amount payable under the Financial Planning Benefit is $5,000 and this amount will only be paid once per Life Insured across all policies issued by us in respect of that Life Insured;
• The Financial Planning Benefit is only payable for the reimbursement of fees actually paid to the financial adviser for the preparation of the financial plan where the fees were paid by the person(s) to whom we paid 100% of the Benefit Amount, or by their Immediate Family Member;
• We must receive evidence which (in our reasonable opinion) establishes the financial planning advice received and the financial plan must be received within 12 months of 100% of the Benefit Amount being paid; and
• The financial adviser who provides the financial plan must be an Australian Financial Services Licensee or an Authorised Representative of an Australian Financial Services Licensee.
ai_summary: The Financial Planning Benefit, applicable only when 100% of the Benefit Amount is paid under Life, TPD, or Critical Illness Insurance (and not through superannuation), allows for reimbursement of up to $5,000 for financial planning fees incurred by the insured or their Immediate Family Member. This benefit is limited to one payment per Life Insured across all policies, requires evidence of the financial advice received, and must be claimed within 12 months of the Benefit Amount payment. Additionally, the financial adviser must be licensed under Australian Financial Services regulations.

Section_Title: 2.4 Additional Benefits and Options applicable to Life, TPD and Critical Illness Insurance
content:
Not available when structured through superannuation.

If we pay 100% of the Terminal Illness Benefit, TPD Benefit or Critical Illness Benefit, we will reimburse the accommodation costs of the Life Insured's Immediate Family Member up to a maximum of $250 per day, for a maximum of 14 days for each day:

* the Life Insured is Bed Confined due to the reason for which we paid 100% of the Terminal Illness Benefit, TPD Benefit or Critical Illness Benefit;
* the Life Insured is Bed Confined more than 100 kilometres from their usual place of residence; and
* the Immediate Family Member remains away from their home, having been required to travel more than 100 kilometres from their usual place of residence to be with the Life Insured.

The following conditions also apply to the Long Distance Accommodation Benefit:

* This benefit must be claimed within six weeks of the Terminal Illness Benefit, TPD Benefit or Critical Illness Benefit being paid in full (100% of the Benefit Amount).
* You must provide evidence which (in our reasonable opinion) establishes the Life Insured's Bed Confinement and payment of the accommodation costs.
* If the Life Insured is eligible for this benefit and there is more than one Plan, we will only pay up to a maximum of $250 per day, across all Plans.
ai_summary: The Long Distance Accommodation Benefit provides reimbursement of up to $250 per day for a maximum of 14 days for accommodation costs incurred by an Immediate Family Member when the Life Insured is Bed Confined due to a qualifying condition, and is located more than 100 kilometres from their usual residence. This benefit is only available if 100% of the Terminal Illness, TPD, or Critical Illness Benefit has been paid, must be claimed within six weeks of the benefit payment, and requires evidence of the Life Insured's Bed Confinement and accommodation expenses. If multiple plans are held, the total reimbursement across all plans is capped at $250 per day. Note that this benefit is not applicable when the insurance is structured through superannuation.

Section_Title: 2.4 Additional Benefits and Options applicable to Life, TPD and Critical Illness Insurance
content:
This benefit is not available when structured through superannuation.

If we pay 100% of the Benefit Amount under Life Insurance, Critical Illness Insurance, or TPD Insurance, we will reimburse the costs of up to three grief counselling sessions for the Life Insured, and/or an Immediate Family Member with a counsellor approved by us, acting reasonably (the counsellor should be competent, recognised and appropriately qualified to provide the support). The maximum total amount we will reimburse under the Grief Support Benefit for the Life Insured is $1,000.

This benefit must be exercised within 12 months of 100% of the Benefit Amount being paid.
ai_summary: The Grief Support Benefit, applicable when 100% of the Benefit Amount is paid under Life, TPD, or Critical Illness Insurance (not available through superannuation), reimburses up to $1,000 for three grief counseling sessions for the Life Insured or an Immediate Family Member with an approved counselor. This benefit must be utilized within 12 months of the payment.

Section_Title: 2.4 Additional Benefits and Options applicable to Life, TPD and Critical Illness Insurance
content:
This benefit is not available when structured through superannuation.

A benefit payment of $10,000 will be payable under the Child's Critical Illness Benefit if your child suffers a Child's Critical Illness Event listed under Child's Critical Illness Insurance (Section 2.5). Each event is defined in Section 9. For a benefit to be paid, the specified serious event must meet the full criteria and severity requirements for that event.

A three month qualifying period applies to certain Child's Critical Illness Events. See Section 2.5.2 for details.

The following conditions apply to the Child's Critical Illness Benefit:

* The child must be financially dependent on the Policy Owner.
* The child's age at their next birthday must be between two and 19.
* This benefit will only be paid once for an individual child across all Life Insurance, TPD Insurance or Critical Illness Insurance Plans issued by us.
* This benefit is only payable on a Critical Illness Event which occurred, was diagnosed, or signs and symptoms became apparent on or before the child's first birthday.
* This benefit is not payable on a Child's Critical Illness Event which occurred, was diagnosed, or signs and symptoms leading to the diagnosis became apparent before the Plan or Policy start date.
* The Child's Critical Illness Benefit ends on the Policy anniversary before the Life Insured's youngest child's 19th birthday.
* The Child's Critical Illness Benefit is not payable if the Plan ends or is cancelled.
