ai_summary: Exposure Prone Procedures refer to medical practices where there is a risk of skin contact with sharp instruments, needles, or bone/teeth fragments in areas that are difficult to visualize or access. Understanding this definition is crucial for insurance coverage related to medical malpractice and liability, as it highlights the potential risks involved in certain surgical procedures and may influence policy terms and conditions.

content: Immediate Family Member means spouse, partner, de-facto, children, parents and siblings.
ai_summary: The term "Immediate Family Member" in the insurance document refers to individuals closely related to the insured, specifically including a spouse, partner, de-facto partner, children, parents, and siblings. This definition is crucial for determining coverage eligibility and benefits related to family-related claims or provisions within the policy.

content:
Indexation Factor is the percentage change in the Consumer Price Index (Weighted Average All Capital Cities) as last published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in respect of the 12-month period finishing on 30 September of each year.
This factor will be determined at 30 November each year and applied, where indicated, for the following calendar year. If it is not published by 30 November, the Indexation Factor will be calculated based upon a retail price index we consider replaces it.
If the percentage change in the Consumer Price Index, or any substitute for it, is negative, the Indexation Factor will be taken as zero.
ai_summary: The Indexation Factor is defined as the percentage change in the Consumer Price Index (Weighted Average All Capital Cities) published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics for the 12 months ending on September 30 each year. It is determined annually on November 30 and applied in the following calendar year; if not published by this date, a suitable retail price index will be used instead. In cases where the percentage change is negative, the Indexation Factor will be set to zero, ensuring that it does not adversely affect policy values.

content: Injury means a bodily injury suffered by the Life Insured or Child Insured.
ai_summary: In the context of this insurance document, "Injury" refers specifically to a bodily injury sustained by either the Life Insured or the Child Insured, establishing the scope of coverage for physical harm under the policy.

content: Life Insured means the person whose life is insured under the Life Insurance Plan, TPD Insurance Plan, Critical Illness Insurance Plan or Income Protection Plan.
ai_summary: The term "Life Insured" refers to the individual whose life is covered by various insurance plans, including the Life Insurance Plan, Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) Insurance Plan, Critical Illness Insurance Plan, or Income Protection Plan.

content: Limb means an arm, leg, hand or foot. In respect of this definition, the hand or foot starts from the wrist or ankle joint, respectively.
ai_summary: In the context of insurance, "Limb" is defined as an arm, leg, hand, or foot, with the hand or foot specifically referring to the portion extending from the wrist or ankle joint. This definition is crucial for determining coverage and benefits related to injuries or conditions affecting these body parts.

content: Linked or Linking means the connection of two separate policies whereby the payment under a Plan purchased under one Policy effects a corresponding reduction in the Benefit Amount payable under the other (Linked) Policy and a reduction in the total premium payable.
ai_summary: "Linked or Linking" refers to the relationship between two insurance policies where a benefit payment from one policy reduces the benefit amount and total premium of the other policy. This arrangement allows for coordinated coverage and potential cost savings across linked policies.

content: Long Term Leave is any leave period longer than four weeks such as any unpaid leave, maternity or paternity leave, a sabbatical, or leave taken to allow you to work for a charitable organisation.
ai_summary: Long Term Leave refers to any leave exceeding four weeks, including unpaid leave, maternity or paternity leave, sabbaticals, and time off to work for charitable organizations. This definition is crucial for understanding eligibility and coverage related to insurance benefits during extended absences from work.

content:
Loss of Independent Existence (permanent) means that solely because of Sickness or Injury, the Life Insured:
• is totally and permanently unable to perform at least two of the five Activities of Daily Living without the physical assistance of another person; or
• suffers permanent Significant Cognitive Impairment.
ai_summary: Loss of Independent Existence (permanent) in this insurance context refers to a condition where the Life Insured is unable to perform at least two of the five Activities of Daily Living without assistance due to Sickness or Injury, or experiences permanent Significant Cognitive Impairment. This definition is crucial for determining eligibility for certain benefits under the policy.

Subheading: Loss of use of a Single Limb (permanent)
content: Loss of use of a Single Limb (permanent) means the total and irrecoverable loss of use of one Limb.
ai_summary: Loss of use of a Single Limb (permanent) refers to the complete and irreversible inability to utilize one limb, which is a critical condition recognized in insurance policies for determining eligibility for benefits related to permanent disability.

content: Loss of use of Limbs (permanent) means the total and irrecoverable loss of use of two or more Limbs.
ai_summary: "Loss of use of Limbs (permanent)" refers to the complete and irreversible inability to use two or more limbs, qualifying for specific insurance benefits related to permanent disability. This definition is crucial for determining eligibility for claims under policies that cover permanent loss of function.

Subheading: Loss of Sight in One Eye (permanent)
content: Loss of Sight in One Eye (permanent) means the permanent and irrecoverable loss of sight (whether aided or unaided) in one eye, because of Sickness or Injury to the extent that visual acuity in the eye, on the Snellen Scale after correction by a suitable lens is less than 6/60, or to the extent that the visual field is reduced to 20 degrees or less of arc.
ai_summary: "Loss of Sight in One Eye (permanent)" refers to the irreversible loss of vision in one eye due to Sickness or Injury, defined as having a visual acuity of less than 6/60 on the Snellen Scale, even with corrective lenses, or a visual field reduced to 20 degrees or less. This definition is crucial for determining eligibility for insurance benefits related to vision impairment.

content: Maximum Medical Improvement means that the Life Insured’s recovery from the Sickness or Injury has reached a point where no further recovery or functional improvement is expected even with additional intervention or treatment (medical and non-medical). We will consider all medical information from the Life Insured’s medical providers and will seek independent medical specialist opinion if required, to determine whether Maximum Medical Improvement has been achieved.
ai_summary: Maximum Medical Improvement (MMI) refers to the stage in which the Life Insured's recovery from a Sickness or Injury has plateaued, indicating that no further recovery or functional enhancement is anticipated, even with ongoing treatment. The determination of MMI will involve a review of medical records from the Life Insured's healthcare providers, and may include consultations with independent medical specialists as necessary.

content:
Medical Practitioner means a person who is legally qualified and registered as a Medical Practitioner, other than:
• you or the Life Insured;
• a business partner of yours or the Life Insured; or
• an Immediate Family Member of you or the Life Insured.
If practising other than in Australia, the Medical Practitioner must be approved by us, acting reasonably, and have qualifications equivalent to Australian standards.
Note: Chiropractors, physiotherapists, psychologists and alternative therapy providers are not regarded as Medical Practitioners.
ai_summary: A Medical Practitioner, as defined in this insurance document, is a legally qualified and registered individual who is not you, the Life Insured, their business partner, or an Immediate Family Member. For practitioners operating outside Australia, they must be approved by the insurer and possess qualifications equivalent to Australian standards. Notably, chiropractors, physiotherapists, psychologists, and alternative therapy providers do not qualify as Medical Practitioners under this definition.

content: MSAL refers to Mercer Superannuation (Australia) Limited (ABN 79 004 717 533) (AFSL 235906) as the trustee of TAL Super.
ai_summary: MSAL, or Mercer Superannuation (Australia) Limited, is identified as the trustee of TAL Super, operating under Australian Business Number (ABN) 79 004 717 533 and holding an Australian Financial Services License (AFSL) 235906. This designation establishes MSAL's role in managing superannuation funds, ensuring compliance with regulatory standards in the insurance sector.

content:
Own Occupation under Income Protection means the occupation or business in which the Life Insured was working immediately before the start of the Waiting Period, unless the Life Insured:
• was Unemployed or on Long Term Leave for more than 12 consecutive months immediately before the start of the Waiting Period, ‘Own Occupation’ will be replaced with ‘Any Occupation’; or
• was Unemployed or on Long Term Leave for less than 12 consecutive months immediately before the start of the Waiting Period, ‘Own Occupation’ means the most recent occupation in which the Life Insured was working prior to the start of the Waiting Period.
If you are Self-Employed or work on a contract basis and you have not performed any duties that directly generate income, or your business has not generated any income for more than 12 consecutive months before the start of the Waiting Period, ‘Own Occupation’ has the same meaning as ‘Any Occupation’.
If the Life Insured had been working in more than one occupation that meets these criteria, ‘Own Occupation’ will include all of those occupations.
ai_summary: In the context of Income Protection, "Own Occupation" refers to the job the Life Insured was engaged in immediately before the Waiting Period, unless they were unemployed or on long-term leave for over 12 months, in which case it defaults to "Any Occupation." If the Life Insured was unemployed or on leave for less than 12 months, "Own Occupation" pertains to their most recent job. For self-employed individuals or contractors who have not generated income for over 12 months, "Own Occupation" also equates to "Any Occupation." If the Life Insured held multiple qualifying occupations, all will be considered under "Own Occupation."

Subheading: Own Occupation under Life Insurance, Critical Illness Insurance and TPD Insurance
content:
Own Occupation under Life Insurance, Critical Illness Insurance and TPD Insurance is the occupation in which the Life Insured was working immediately before the Sickness or Injury causing disability.
If the Life Insured had been working in more than one occupation that meets these criteria, ‘Own Occupation’ will include all of those occupations.
ai_summary: The term "Own Occupation" in the context of Life Insurance, Critical Illness Insurance, and Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) Insurance refers to the specific job the Life Insured was engaged in immediately prior to a Sickness or Injury that leads to disability. If the Life Insured held multiple qualifying occupations at that time, "Own Occupation" encompasses all such roles.

content:
Paralysis Support Benefit Amount means the additional amount we will pay (under the Paralysis Support Benefit) such that the aggregate amount paid under both the Critical Illness Benefit and Paralysis Support Benefit is the lesser of:
• two times the Critical Illness Insurance Benefit Amount; and
• $2,000,000.
ai_summary: The Paralysis Support Benefit Amount refers to the extra payment provided under the Paralysis Support Benefit, ensuring that the total payout from both the Critical Illness Benefit and the Paralysis Support Benefit does not exceed the lesser of twice the Critical Illness Insurance Benefit Amount or $2,000,000.

content:
Partially Unable to Work means that solely because of Sickness or Injury, the Life Insured is:
• working (whether or not for remuneration) in a reduced capacity or capable of working in a reduced capacity;
• following the advice and treatment plan of a Medical Practitioner in relation to the Sickness or Injury; and
• not capable of working more than 80% of the Life Insured’s usual average working hours in the 12 months immediately before the start of the Waiting Period. The usual average working hours immediately before the start of the Waiting Period will be limited to 40 hours a week (if the Life Insured is working more than 40 hours a week).
Where Income Protection has been structured through superannuation, the Life Insured must also satisfy the SIS definition for Temporary Incapacity or Permanent Incapacity.
ai_summary: "Partially Unable to Work" refers to a situation where the Life Insured, due to Sickness or Injury, is either working in a reduced capacity or is capable of doing so, while adhering to a Medical Practitioner’s treatment plan. Additionally, the Life Insured must not be able to work more than 80% of their average working hours from the 12 months prior to the Waiting Period, capped at 40 hours per week if they typically worked more. For Income Protection through superannuation, the Life Insured must also meet the SIS criteria for Temporary or Permanent Incapacity.

content: Plan means the insurance benefits and applicable options under Life Insurance, TPD Insurance, Critical Illness Insurance, Child’s Critical Illness Insurance and Income Protection, depending on the terms of the Policy and applicable Policy Schedule, that apply to you when your Policy is in force.
ai_summary: The term "Plan" refers to the specific insurance benefits and options available to you under various coverages, including Life Insurance, Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) Insurance, Critical Illness Insurance, Child’s Critical Illness Insurance, and Income Protection, as outlined in your Policy and its Schedule, while the Policy remains active.

content: Policy means the Accelerated Protection Policy under the terms and conditions set out in this PDS.
ai_summary: The term "Policy" refers to the Accelerated Protection Policy, which is governed by the specific terms and conditions outlined in this Product Disclosure Statement (PDS). This definition establishes the framework for understanding the coverage and obligations associated with the insurance product.

content: Policy Owner means the person or company that legally owns the Policy. Where Accelerated Protection is structured through a superannuation fund, the trustee of that superannuation fund will be the Policy Owner that holds the Policy on behalf of the member.
ai_summary: The Policy Owner is the individual or entity that legally holds the insurance policy. In cases where the Accelerated Protection is arranged through a superannuation fund, the trustee of that fund acts as the Policy Owner, managing the policy on behalf of the fund member.

content: Policy Schedule refers to the documentation that identifies the Policy Owner, the Life Insured, the type of Plan(s) and options applicable to the Policy, the amount of coverage, the special conditions that apply, the Plan start and end date and premium details (amount and payment frequency). The Policy Schedule is a legal document and forms part of the insurance contract.
ai_summary: The Policy Schedule is a crucial legal document within the insurance contract that details the Policy Owner, Life Insured, applicable Plan types and options, coverage amount, special conditions, Plan duration, and premium specifics, including amount and payment frequency.

content:
Pre-Claim Earnings under Income Protection means:
• if Self-Employed, the Life Insured’s average Earnings over the last two financial years that have ended immediately before the start of the Waiting Period; or
• if an Employee (and the Life Insured is not Self-Employed), the Life Insured’s average Earnings over the consecutive 12-month period immediately before the start of the Waiting Period.
Pre-Claim Earnings will increase by the Indexation Factor on each anniversary from the start of the Totally Unable to Work Benefit or the Partially Unable to Work Benefit becomes payable.
If the Life Insured has been on Long Term Leave or was Unemployed for up to 12 months prior to the start of the Waiting Period, Pre-Claim Earnings will be calculated based on the period immediately before the Life Insured went on Long Term Leave or became Unemployed.
If Income Protection is structured through superannuation, the SIS rules and regulation must be met.
ai_summary: Pre-Claim Earnings under Income Protection refers to the average earnings of the Life Insured prior to the Waiting Period, calculated as the average over the last two financial years for self-employed individuals or the past 12 months for employees. These earnings are subject to annual increases based on the Indexation Factor once benefits begin. If the Life Insured has been on Long Term Leave or unemployed for up to 12 months before the Waiting Period, earnings will be calculated based on the period immediately prior to that leave or unemployment. Additionally, if the Income Protection is provided through superannuation, compliance with SIS rules and regulations is required.

content:
Rehabilitation Program means a program or plan:
• designed to assist the Life Insured in returning to a Working Occupation; and
• developed by an appropriately qualified vocational or occupational rehabilitation specialist.
General medical consultations and medical therapy consultations, including but not limited to, physiotherapy, psychotherapy and hydrotherapy, are excluded.
ai_summary: The Rehabilitation Program is a structured initiative aimed at helping the Life Insured return to their Working Occupation, crafted by a qualified vocational or occupational rehabilitation specialist. It is important to note that general medical consultations and therapies, such as physiotherapy, psychotherapy, and hydrotherapy, are not covered under this program.

content: Self-Employed means the Life Insured directly or indirectly owns all or part of the business in which their work is performed including where the business operates under a company structure (ignoring shares in publicly listed companies).
ai_summary: In insurance terms, "Self-Employed" refers to the Life Insured who has direct or indirect ownership of a business where they work, encompassing various business structures but excluding shares in publicly traded companies. This definition is crucial for determining coverage and benefits related to the insured's employment status.

Subheading: Serious and Permanent Incapacity or Seriously and Permanently Incapacitated
ai_summary: "Serious and Permanent Incapacity" refers to a condition where the Life Insured, due to Sickness or Injury, experiences permanent incapacity that meets specific severity criteria. Additionally, mental illnesses are evaluated solely under their designated category, and for chronic pain conditions, the Life Insured must have undergone a recognized multi-disciplinary pain management program and received care from a pain specialist for at least six months, with no anticipated further functional improvement.

content:
Category | Serious Incapacity requirement
---|---
Cardiac and respiratory condition | The Life Insured meets one of the following:
• suffers an irreversible respiratory condition and is on permanent oxygen therapy; or
• suffers an irreversible cardiac condition to the degree of at least Class 3 of the New York Heart Association Classification.
Mental illness | The Life Insured has a diagnosed mental disorder, and solely due to the mental disorder meets at least four of the following:
• Self-care and independent living: Cannot live independently without regular support. Needs prompting to shower daily and wear clean clothes. Is not able to prepare own meals and frequently misses meals if not prompted to eat. Requires family member or community nurse visits 3 times every week to ensure minimum level of hygiene and nutrition.
• Social and/or recreational activities: Rarely goes out to social and/or recreational events, and only when prompted by family member or close friend. Not actively involved, remains quiet and withdrawn.
• Social functioning: Unable to form or sustain long term relationships and loss of most pre-existing relationships (e.g. lost partner, close friends, own children, elderly parent).
• Travel: Cannot travel away from own residence without support person due to severe anxiety or cognitive impairment.
• Concentration: Can only read a few lines of text before losing concentration. Has difficulty following simple instructions. Concentration deficits obvious even during brief conversation. Needs regular assistance from relatives or community services.
Cognitive impairment (impairment as a result of Sickness or Injury other than mental illness) | The Life Insured suffers a deterioration or loss of intellectual capacity that results in a requirement for a full-time permanent caregiver.
Blindness | The Life Insured has permanent and irrecoverable loss of sight in of both eyes as a result of Sickness or Injury to the extent that visual acuity in both eyes, on a Snellen Scale after correction by suitable lenses is less than 6/60, or to the extent that the visual field is reduced to 20 degrees or less of arc. Visual acuity cannot be improved with corrective lenses or surgery.
Terminal conditions | The Life Insured has an incurable Sickness or Injury and:
• has a life expectancy of less than 12 months; or
• requires palliative care (i.e. care or treatment to improve the quality of living). The palliative care must be provided by an accredited medical provider/facility.
Universal | The Life Insured is totally and permanently unable to perform at least two of the five Activities of Daily Living without the physical assistance of another person.
The Life Insured is considered capable of performing the task if they can perform the task using or wearing any prosthesis or assistive device that is appropriate.
Specified conditions | The Life Insured has been unequivocally diagnosed by an appropriate specialist Medical Practitioner with one of the following:
• paraplegia, hemiplegia or quadriplegia
• end stage chronic kidney, lung, heart or liver failure
• motor neurone disease
• dementia
• Parkinson’s disease
ai_summary: Section 9 defines the "Serious Incapacity" requirement for insurance coverage, outlining specific conditions under which the Life Insured qualifies. These include irreversible cardiac or respiratory conditions, diagnosed mental disorders requiring significant support, cognitive impairments necessitating full-time caregiving, permanent blindness, terminal illnesses with a life expectancy of less than 12 months, and total inability to perform two of five Activities of Daily Living. Additionally, specified conditions such as paraplegia, end-stage organ failure, and neurodegenerative diseases also qualify for serious incapacity status, ensuring comprehensive coverage for individuals facing severe health challenges.

content:
Sickness means an illness or disease suffered by the Life Insured or Child Insured, as confirmed by a Medical Practitioner.

Significant Cognitive Impairment means a deterioration or loss of intellectual capacity that results in a requirement for a full-time permanent caregiver.

SIS means the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 (Cth) or the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulation 1994 (Cth), as applicable.

SMSF means self-managed superannuation fund.

Standalone means Plans which are held independently of each other and when a benefit is paid under one Plan, it does not reduce the Benefit Amount for any other Standalone Plans held.

Structured through superannuation means Accelerated Protection is owned by the trustee of a fund (which may be TAL Super, a retail superannuation fund which we have an agreement with or a self-managed superannuation fund) for one or more members of the fund.

Super Contribution Benefit Amount under the Super Contribution Option means the monthly benefit shown in your Policy Schedule plus any increases under the Inflation Protection Benefit.

Superlink or Superlinked means the connection of two separate Policies, one issued to the trustee of a superannuation fund and the other issued outside of superannuation. In the event no amount is payable under the Policy structured through superannuation, or the amount payable is restricted, a payment may be made through the Policy structured outside superannuation, subject to the Life Insured meeting the terms and conditions. The maximum benefits payable under both Policies will never exceed the amount that would have been payable under a single Policy structured outside superannuation.

TAL Services means TAL Services Limited (ACN 076 105 130), a related body corporate of TAL that provides administration and other services in relation to TAL Super.

TAL Super means a plan within the Retail Division in the Mercer Super Trust (ABN 19 905 422 981) sponsored by TAL Services Limited.

Terminally Ill and Terminal Illness means an illness or condition where, after having regard to the current treatment or such treatment as the Life Insured may reasonably be expected to receive, the Life Insured has a life expectancy of less than 12 months.

When Life Insurance is structured through superannuation, the Life Insured must also satisfy the SIS definition of Terminal Medical Condition.
ai_summary: This section defines key insurance terms: "Sickness" refers to an illness confirmed by a Medical Practitioner; "Significant Cognitive Impairment" indicates a loss of intellectual capacity requiring full-time care. "SIS" pertains to the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993, while "SMSF" denotes a self-managed superannuation fund. "Standalone" plans operate independently, ensuring benefits from one do not affect others. "Structured through superannuation" means insurance is held by a fund trustee, and "Superlink" connects policies within and outside superannuation. "TAL Services" refers to the administrative body for TAL Super, which is part of the Mercer Super Trust. "Terminally Ill" describes a

content:
Total and Permanent Disability and Totally and Permanently Disabled when 'Any Occupation' is shown in your Policy Schedule means that solely because of Sickness or Injury and after all reasonable treatment and rehabilitation has been undertaken:

* the Life Insured has not been working in any occupation for three consecutive months and, in our opinion, after consideration of medical and any other evidence, is incapacitated to such an extent as to render the Life Insured unlikely ever to be able to work in any occupation for which they are reasonably suited by training, education or experience which would pay remuneration at a rate greater than 25% of the Life Insured's Earnings during their last 12 months of work; or
* the Life Insured is Totally and Permanently Disabled under the 'ADL' definition.

When cover is structured through superannuation, the Life Insured must also satisfy the SIS definition of Permanent Incapacity.

Total and Permanent Disability and Totally and Permanently Disabled when 'Own Occupation' is shown in your Policy Schedule means that solely because of Sickness or Injury and after all reasonable treatment and rehabilitation has been undertaken:

* the Life Insured has not been working in their Own Occupation for three consecutive months and in our opinion, after consideration of medical and any other evidence, is incapacitated to such an extent as to render the Life Insured unlikely ever to be able to work in their Own Occupation; or
* the Life Insured has suffered permanent Whole Person Impairment of at least 25% and has not been working in any occupation, and, in our opinion, after consideration of medical and any other evidence, is incapacitated to such an extent as to render the Life Insured unlikely ever to be able to work in any occupation for which they are reasonably suited by training, education or experience which would pay remuneration at a rate greater than 25% of the Life Insured's Earnings during their last 12 months of work; or
* the Life Insured is Totally and Permanently Disabled under the 'ADL' definition.
ai_summary: Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) is defined based on the Life Insured's inability to work due to Sickness or Injury, with two classifications: 'Any Occupation' and 'Own Occupation.' For 'Any Occupation,' the Life Insured must be unable to work in any role for three consecutive months and deemed unlikely to earn more than 25% of their previous earnings. For 'Own Occupation,' the criteria include not working in their specific role for three months and being unlikely to return to that occupation, or having a permanent Whole Person Impairment of at least 25%. Additionally, if coverage is through superannuation, the Life Insured must meet the SIS definition of Permanent Incapacity.

content:
Total and Permanent Disability and Totally and Permanently Disabled when 'ADL' (Activities of Daily Living) is shown in your Policy Schedule or when the 'TPD ADL' definition is applicable, means that solely because of Sickness or Injury the Life Insured:

* is totally and permanently unable to perform at least two of the five Activities of Daily Living without the physical assistance of another person;
* suffers Blindness (permanent);
* suffers Loss of use of Limbs (permanent);
* suffers Significant Cognitive Impairment; or
* suffers a mental disorder based on a recognised diagnostic system, and solely due to the mental disorder permanently satisfies or meets at least four of the five Mental Illness categories after reaching Maximum Medical Improvement.

Mental illness categories:
The Life Insured has a diagnosed mental disorder and meets at least four of the following:

* Self-care and independent living: Cannot live independently without regular support. Needs prompting to shower daily and wear clean clothes. Is not able to prepare own meals and frequently misses meals if not prompted to eat. Requires family member or community nurse visits at least 3 times every week to ensure minimum level of hygiene and nutrition.
* Social and/or recreational activities: Rarely goes out to social and/or recreational events, and only when prompted by a family member or a close friend. Not actively involved, remains quiet and withdrawn.
* Travel: Cannot travel away from own residence without support upon own desire due to severe anxiety or cognitive impairment.
* Social functioning: Unable to form or sustain long term relationships and loss of most pre-existing relationships (e.g. lost partner, close friends). Unable to care for dependants (e.g. own children, elderly parent).
* Concentration: Can only read a few lines of text before losing concentration. Has difficulty following simple instructions. Concentration deficits obvious even during brief conversation. Needs regular assistance from relatives or community services.

If the Life Insured permanently satisfies or meets the Mental Illness categories above, it must be solely due to a mental disorder diagnosed on a recognised diagnostic system.

When cover is structured through superannuation, the Life Insured must also satisfy the SIS definition of Permanent Incapacity.

Totally Unable to Work means that solely because of Sickness or Injury, the Life Insured is:

* not working in any capacity (this includes full-time, part-time and casual, whether or not for remuneration;
ai_summary: Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) is defined as the Life Insured's inability to perform at least two of five Activities of Daily Living (ADLs) without assistance, or suffering from permanent blindness, loss of limb use, significant cognitive impairment, or a diagnosed mental disorder meeting specific criteria. For mental disorders, the insured must demonstrate at least four of five categories related to self-care, social activities, travel, social functioning, and concentration deficits. Additionally, if coverage is through superannuation, the Life Insured must meet the SIS definition of Permanent Incapacity. "Totally Unable to Work" indicates the insured is not working in any capacity due to sickness or injury.

content:
* following the advice and treatment plan of a Medical Practitioner in relation to the Sickness or Injury, and
* unable to perform all the duties necessary to generate income in the Life Insured's Own Occupation* (if the Life Insured is able to perform any duties necessary to generate income in their Own Occupation, they are not Totally Unable to Work).

*If the 'to age 65' Benefit Period applies, following the first 24 months of the Claim Period, Own Occupation will be replaced with Any Occupation.

Underwriting is a process by which we assess risks associated with your application for insurance. The underwriting process is based on the life to be insured's health and other relevant factors, such as occupation, pursuits and income.

Unemployed and Unemployment mean that the Life Insured is not employed or working in any Working Occupation. It does not include sick leave, sabbatical, long service, maternity or paternity leave.

Waiting Period means the period (in consecutive days) between the Life Insured becoming Totally Unable to Work or Partially Unable to Work, and the Totally Unable to Work Benefit or the Partially Unable to Work Benefit becoming payable.

If the Life Insured does not consult a Medical Practitioner concerning the Sickness or Injury causing disability within seven days of the Sickness starting or the Injury occurring, the Waiting Period will start when the Life Insured consults a Medical Practitioner.

War or an act of war means armed aggression, whether declared or not, by a country or organisation, resisted or not.

We, us and our mean TAL Life Limited (ABN 70 050 109 450) (AFSL 237848).

Whole Person Impairment means where a payment depends on the Life Insured meeting criteria based on the Whole Person Impairment, the calculation is to be based on the latest edition of the American Medical Association publication titled Guides to the Evaluation of Permanent Impairment until an equivalent Australian guide, sanctioned by the Australian Medical Association, has been produced, at which time the calculation in the relevant Australian guide will apply.

Working Occupation means an occupation in which the Life Insured is working and as a result, is expected to generate Earnings.

You and your means the Policy Owner and/or the Life Insured as applicable or as the context requires, unless indicated otherwise.
ai_summary: This section defines key terms related to insurance coverage, including the conditions for Total and Partial Disability benefits, which require adherence to a Medical Practitioner’s treatment plan and the inability to perform duties in the Life Insured's Own Occupation. It outlines the underwriting process, clarifies definitions of unemployment, waiting periods for benefits, and the implications of consulting a Medical Practitioner. Additionally, it specifies that benefits may shift from Own Occupation to Any Occupation after 24 months if the 'to age 65' Benefit Period applies, and it details the criteria for assessing Whole Person Impairment based on recognized medical guidelines.

content:
The following definitions have been reproduced from SIS. You should be aware that if any of these definitions are changed in SIS, the corresponding definition reproduced here will be obsolete and replaced by the amended definition in SIS.

Permanent Incapacity in relation to a member of a superannuation fund means ill-health (whether physical or mental), where the trustee is reasonably satisfied that the member is unlikely, because of the ill-health, to engage in gainful employment for which the member is reasonably qualified by education, training or experience.

Temporary Incapacity in relation to a member of a superannuation fund who has ceased to be gainfully employed (including a member who has ceased temporarily to receive any gain or reward under a continuing arrangement for the member to be gainfully employed), means ill-health (whether physical or mental) that caused the member to cease to be gainfully employed but does not constitute Permanent Incapacity.

Terminal Medical Condition exists in relation to a member of a superannuation fund at a particular time if the following circumstances exist:
• two registered medical practitioners have certified, jointly or separately, that the person suffers from an illness, or has incurred an injury, that is likely to result in the death of the person within a period (the certification period) that ends not more than 24 months after the date of the certification;
• at least one of the registered medical practitioners is a specialist practicing in an area related to the illness or injury suffered by the person;
• for each of the certificates, the certification period has not ended.
ai_summary: This section outlines key definitions from the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act (SIS) relevant to superannuation fund members. "Permanent Incapacity" refers to a member's ill-health that prevents them from engaging in gainful employment, while "Temporary Incapacity" applies to members who have temporarily ceased employment due to ill-health but do not meet the criteria for Permanent Incapacity. A "Terminal Medical Condition" is defined as an illness or injury certified by two medical practitioners, one being a specialist, indicating that the member is likely to die within 24 months. Changes to these definitions in SIS will render the corresponding definitions in this document obsolete.

Subheading: 9.3 Critical Illness events and specified condition definition
ai_summary: Section 9.3 of the Life Insurance Code of Practice outlines the assessment of claims for critical illness events when a policy's medical definitions reference outdated diagnostic methods. It defines "Angioplasty" as the procedure to correct coronary artery blockages and specifies "Angioplasty for Triple Vessel Disease" as the first-time treatment of three major coronary arteries in one session, with benefits applicable if a second procedure is needed within two months. For further details, refer to the 'Important information about this document' section of the PDS.

Subheading: 9.3 Critical Illness events and specified condition definition
ai_summary: Section 9.3 defines "Aortic Surgery" as procedures to repair conditions affecting the aorta, including aneurysms and dissections, specifically excluding its branches. "Aplastic Anaemia" is characterized by bone marrow failure leading to significant blood cell deficiencies (anaemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia) and necessitating treatments such as blood transfusions, marrow stimulants, immunosuppressants, or bone marrow transplants.

Subheading: 9.3 Critical Illness events and specified condition definition
content:
Benign Brain Tumour (resulting in irreversible neurological deficit) means a non-cancerous tumour in the brain (excludes cranial nerves), meninges, pituitary gland or spinal cord, resulting in an irreversible neurological deficit which has caused:
• permanent Whole Person Impairment of at least 25%; or
• the Life Insured to be totally and permanently unable to perform any one of the Activities of Daily Living.
The presence of the underlying tumour must be confirmed by CT Scan, MRI or other imaging studies. Cysts, granulomas, vascular aneurysms or haematomas are not covered.
ai_summary: A Benign Brain Tumour, defined for critical illness coverage, is a non-cancerous brain tumour (excluding cranial nerves) that results in an irreversible neurological deficit, leading to either a permanent Whole Person Impairment of at least 25% or total and permanent inability to perform any Activities of Daily Living. Diagnosis must be confirmed through CT Scan, MRI, or other imaging studies, and conditions such as cysts, granulomas, vascular aneurysms, or haematomas are not eligible for coverage.

Subheading: 9.3 Critical Illness events and specified condition definition
content:
Blindness (permanent) means the permanent and irrecoverable loss of sight (whether aided or unaided) in both eyes as a result of Sickness or Injury to the extent that visual acuity in both eyes, on a Snellen Scale after correction by suitable lens is less than 6/60, or to the extent that the visual field is reduced to 20 degrees or less of arc.

Cancer (of specified criteria) means any malignant tumours diagnosed with histological or cytological confirmation and characterised by:
• the uncontrolled growth of malignant cells; and
• invasion and destruction of normal tissue beyond the basement membrane.
The term malignant tumour includes lymphoma (including Hodgkin’s and non-Hodgkin’s disease), leukaemia, multiple myeloma and malignant bone marrow disorders.
The following are not covered:
• All tumours which are histologically described as any of the following:
a. pre-malignant;
b. non-invasive (includes tumours that are classified as Tis, Cis or pTa unless stated otherwise);
c. low-grade or high-grade dysplasia; or
d. borderline or low malignant potential.
• All carcinoma in situ except the following:
a. Carcinoma in situ of the breast which requires the removal of the entire breast.
b. Carcinoma of the breast which requires breast conserving surgery with either radiotherapy or chemotherapy.
c. Carcinoma in situ of the testicle that requires removal of the entire testicle.
• All skin melanomas unless the melanoma:
a. has evidence of metastasis;
b. is at least Clark level 3;
c. is showing signs of ulceration; or
d. is greater than 1.0mm maximum thickness using the Breslow method.
ai_summary: Section 9.3 defines critical illness events, specifying "Blindness" as the permanent loss of sight in both eyes with visual acuity below 6/60 or a visual field reduced to 20 degrees or less. "Cancer" is defined as malignant tumors confirmed histologically or cytologically, characterized by uncontrolled growth and tissue invasion. Notably excluded are pre-malignant tumors, non-invasive tumors, low-grade dysplasia, and certain carcinoma in situ, with specific exceptions for breast and testicular cancers. Additionally, skin melanomas are only covered if they meet criteria related to metastasis, Clark level, ulceration, or thickness.

Subheading: 9.3 Critical Illness events and specified condition definition
content:
Carcinoma In Situ (of specified site) means the Life Insured has a carcinoma in situ, characterised by a focal autonomous new growth of carcinomatous cells, which has not yet resulted in the invasion and destruction of normal tissues beyond the basement membrane. The tumour must be classified as Tis according to the TNM staging method or FIGO Stage 0.

Only Carcinomas In Situ of the following sites are covered:
• Breast
• Cervix (Cervical Intraepithelial Neoplasia (CIN) (classified as CIN-1 and CIN-2 are excluded).
• Endometrium
• Fallopian Tube (the tumour must be limited to the tubal mucosa)
• Ovary
• Penis
• Perineum
• Testicle
• Vagina
• Vulva
ai_summary: Carcinoma In Situ (of specified sites) is defined as a localized carcinoma characterized by abnormal cell growth that has not invaded surrounding tissues, classified as Tis under TNM staging or FIGO Stage 0. Coverage is limited to specific sites, including the breast, endometrium, fallopian tube (limited to tubal mucosa), ovary, penis, perineum, testicle, vagina, and vulva, while excluding certain classifications such as Cervical Intraepithelial Neoplasia (CIN-1 and CIN-2).

Subheading: 9.3 Critical Illness events and specified condition definition
content:
Cardiomyopathy (permanent) means a disease of the heart muscle characterised by structural, functional and/or electrophysiological dysfunction of the heart muscle, resulting in significant permanent and irreversible cardiac impairment to the degree of at least Class 3 of the New York Heart Association classification of cardiac impairment.

Chronic Kidney Failure (undergoing permanent dialysis) means undergoing permanent dialysis treatment prescribed by renal physician due to impairment of total kidney function to a severity constituting end stage kidney failure.

Chronic Liver Failure (resulting in permanent symptoms) means end-stage decompensated liver failure characterised by the presence of liver cirrhosis and development of complications of cirrhosis, including jaundice, ascites and/or encephalopathy.
ai_summary: Section 9.3 defines critical illness events as specific medical conditions that qualify for insurance coverage. Cardiomyopathy is characterized by significant and irreversible heart muscle dysfunction, classified as at least Class 3 by the New York Heart Association. Chronic Kidney Failure refers to patients requiring permanent dialysis due to end-stage kidney impairment. Chronic Liver Failure is defined as end-stage liver failure with cirrhosis and complications such as jaundice, ascites, or encephalopathy, resulting in permanent symptoms. These definitions establish the criteria for coverage under the policy for severe health conditions.

Subheading: 9.3 Critical Illness events and specified condition definition
content: json Section_Title : 9 Definitions , Subheading : N A , content : Chronic Lung Failure (on permanent oxygen therapy) means end-stage lung disease with a consistent pulmonary function test result of: n FEV1 less than 40 predicted; or n a DLCO less than 40 predicted; and n on permanent oxygen therapy. , content_label : text , Section_Title : 9 Definitions , Subheading : N A , content : Coma (of specified severity) means a state of unconsciousness which requires mechanical ventilation by means of tracheal intubation for at least three consecutive days (72 hours). , content_label : text , Section_Title : 9 Definitions , Subheading : N A , content : Congenital Blindness (permanent) means a congenital, total and permanent loss of sight in both eyes whether aided or unaided, confirmed by an appropriate specialist Medical Practitioner. , content_label : text , Section_Title : 9 Definitions , Subheading : N A , content : Congenital Deafness (permanent) means irrecoverable profound loss of all hearing in both ears, resulting in an auditory threshold of 91 decibels or greater, averaged at frequencies 500, 1000 and 3000 hertz, both natural and assisted, as a result of a congenital condition. ai_summary: Section 9.3 of the insurance document defines several critical illness events and specified conditions relevant for coverage. Key definitions include Chronic Lung Failure, characterized by severe pulmonary impairment requiring permanent oxygen therapy; Coma, defined as a state necessitating mechanical ventilation for at least 72 hours; and Congenital Blindness, which refers to a total and permanent loss of sight confirmed by a specialist. Additionally, Congenital Deafness and permanent Deafness are defined by profound hearing loss diagnosed by a medical practitioner, while Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery is specified as a treatment for coronary artery disease. These definitions establish the criteria for claims related to these serious health conditions.

Subheading: Medically-Acquired HIV (contracted from a medical procedure or operation)
content:
means accidental infection, after the Plan start date, with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) where the virus was acquired in Australia by the Life Insured from one of the following medically necessary events conducted by a recognised and registered health professional:
* a blood transfusion;
* transfusion with blood products;
* organ transplant to the Life Insured;
* assisted reproductive techniques; or
* a medical procedure or operation performed by a Medical Practitioner or dentist.
Notification and proof of the incident will be required via a statement from the appropriate Statutory Health Authority that the infection was medically acquired.
HIV infection transmitted by any other means including sexual activity or the use of drugs, other than as prescribed by a Medical Practitioner for the Life Insured is excluded.
This Critical Illness event will not apply and no payment will be made where:
* the Life Insured has not followed the advice of a Medical Practitioner; or
* a functional cure has become available.
A functional cure is where the Life Insured had:
* been fully cured from the HIV infection; or
* achieved a level of health where the HIV infection does not prevent the Life Insured from working in their Own Occupation. We will make this assessment based on the opinion from the relevant medical specialist and/or relevant governing body of the Life Insured’s profession, if applicable.
ai_summary: Medically-Acquired HIV refers to accidental infection with HIV contracted in Australia after the Plan start date through medically necessary events, such as blood transfusions or organ transplants, conducted by a registered health professional. Coverage requires notification and proof from a Statutory Health Authority, and excludes infections from non-medical means, such as sexual activity or drug use. Benefits are void if the Life Insured does not follow medical advice or if a functional cure is available, defined as being fully cured or achieving a health status that allows them to work in their Own Occupation, as assessed by relevant medical specialists.

Subheading: Meningococcal Septicaemia (resulting in significant permanent impairment)
content:
means the unequivocal diagnosis of meningococcal septicaemia causing:
* permanent Whole Person Impairment of at least 25%;
or
* the Life Insured being totally and permanently unable to perform any one of the Activities of Daily Living.
The diagnosis must be confirmed by blood culture analysis.
ai_summary: Meningococcal Septicaemia, as defined in this insurance document, refers to a confirmed diagnosis resulting in either a permanent Whole Person Impairment of at least 25% or the Life Insured's total and permanent inability to perform any one of the Activities of Daily Living, with the diagnosis requiring validation through blood culture analysis.

Subheading: Multiple Sclerosis (with multiple episodes of neurological deficit and persisting neurological abnormalities)
content:
means a disease characterised by demyelination in the brain and/or spinal cord. Multiple Sclerosis must be unequivocally diagnosed by an appropriate specialist Medical Practitioner. There must be more than one episode of well-defined neurological deficit with persisting neurological abnormalities.
Neurological investigations such as lumbar puncture, MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) evidence of lesions in the central nervous system, evoked visual responses, and evoked auditory responses are required to confirm diagnosis.
ai_summary: Multiple Sclerosis is defined as a disease involving demyelination in the brain and/or spinal cord, requiring a definitive diagnosis from a qualified specialist. For insurance purposes, the diagnosis must include multiple episodes of neurological deficits with lasting abnormalities, supported by neurological investigations such as MRI, lumbar puncture, and evoked response tests.

content: means the unequivocal diagnosis of muscular dystrophy by an appropriate specialist Medical Practitioner. The diagnosis must be supported by appropriate clinical investigations including genetic test, muscle biopsy or electromyography.
ai_summary: Muscular dystrophy is defined as a definitive diagnosis made by a qualified Medical Practitioner, which must be substantiated by relevant clinical investigations such as genetic testing, muscle biopsy, or electromyography. This definition is crucial for determining coverage and benefits related to muscular dystrophy under the insurance policy.

content:
means the unequivocal diagnosis of meningitis where the condition is characterised by severe inflammation of the meninges of the brain resulting in permanent neurological deficit causing:
* permanent Whole Person Impairment of at least 25%;
or
* the Life Insured being totally and permanently unable to perform any one of the Activities of Daily Living.
The diagnosis must be confirmed by structural brain imaging, EEG and/or cerebrospinal fluid analysis.
ai_summary: Meningitis, as defined in this insurance document, refers to a confirmed diagnosis characterized by severe inflammation of the brain's meninges, leading to permanent neurological deficits. This condition must result in either a Whole Person Impairment of at least 25% or total and permanent inability to perform any Activities of Daily Living, with diagnosis supported by structural brain imaging, EEG, or cerebrospinal fluid analysis.

content:
means infection, after the Plan start date, with Hepatitis B or C where the infection is acquired because of:
* an accident arising out of the Life Insured’s normal occupation; or
* a malicious act of another person or persons arising out of the Life Insured’s normal occupation.
Proof of new Hepatitis B or C infection must be registered within six months of the accident or malicious act.
Any incident giving rise to a potential claim must be:
* reported to the relevant authority or employer within seven days of the incident;
* reported to us with proof of the incident within 30 days after the incident; and
* supported by a negative Hepatitis B or C test taken within seven days of the incident.
The infection must manifest itself within six months of the accident or malicious act.
This Critical Illness Event will not apply, and no payment will be made if:
* the infection occurred directly or indirectly, as a result of an intentional self-inflicted act by the Life Insured;
* the Life Insured has not followed the advice of a Medical Practitioner;
* the Hepatitis B or C infection resulted from sexual activity or drug use not medically prescribed for the Life Insured; or
* the Life Insured achieves a functional cure.
A functional cure is where the Life Insured had:
* been fully cured from the infection; or
* achieved a level of health where the infection does not prevent the Life Insured from working in their Own Occupation. We will make this assessment based on the opinion from the relevant medical specialist and/or governing body of the Life Insured’s profession, if applicable.
ai_summary: Occupationally-Acquired Hepatitis B or C refers to infections contracted after the Plan start date due to accidents or malicious acts related to the Life Insured's occupation. Claims must be reported to the relevant authority within seven days and to the insurer within 30 days, accompanied by a negative test result taken within seven days. The infection must manifest within six months of the incident. Exclusions include infections resulting from self-inflicted acts, non-compliance with medical advice, sexually transmitted infections, drug use, or achieving a functional cure, defined as being fully cured or able to work without impairment.

content:
means infection after the Plan start date, with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) where the infection is acquired because of:
* an accident arising out of the Life Insured’s normal occupation; or
* a malicious act of another person or persons arising out of the Life Insured’s normal occupation.
The infection must be diagnosed with a positive anti-HIV antibody test result within six months of the reported occurrence. Proof of the new HIV infection must be reported and registered within six months of the accident or malicious act.
Any incident giving rise to a potential claim must be:
* reported to the relevant authority or employer within seven days of the incident;
* reported to us with proof of the incident within 30 days after the incident; and
* supported by a negative HIV test taken within seven days of the incident.
This Critical Illness event will not apply and no payment will be made if:
* the infection occurred directly or indirectly, as a result of an intentional self-inflicted act by the Life Insured;
* the Life Insured has not followed the advice of a Medical Practitioner; or
* the HIV infection resulted from sexual activity or drug use not medically prescribed for the Life Insured; or
* the Life Insured achieves a functional cure.
A functional cure is where the Life Insured had:
* been fully cured from the infection; or
* achieved a level of health where the infection does not prevent the Life Insured from working in their Own Occupation. We will make this assessment based on the opinion from the relevant medical specialist and/or governing body of the Life Insured’s profession, if applicable.
ai_summary: Occupationally-Acquired HIV refers to HIV infection contracted after the Plan start date due to an accident or malicious act related to the Life Insured's occupation, with diagnosis confirmed by a positive anti-HIV antibody test within six months. Claims require timely reporting to authorities and the insurer, including proof of the incident and a negative HIV test within specified timeframes. Exclusions apply for infections resulting from self-inflicted acts, non-compliance with medical advice, or those arising from non-prescribed sexual activity or drug use. Additionally, no payment will be made if the Life Insured achieves a functional cure, defined as complete recovery or a health status that allows them to work in their own occupation.

content: means the undergoing of open heart surgery for the surgical treatment of a cardiac defect, cardiac aneurysm or benign cardiac tumour.
ai_summary: Open Heart Surgery is defined as the surgical procedure performed to treat a cardiac defect, cardiac aneurysm, or benign cardiac tumor. This definition is crucial for determining coverage eligibility and benefits under the insurance policy, as it specifies the medical conditions that qualify for open heart surgery claims.

Subheading: Out of Hospital Cardiac Arrest (requiring cardiopulmonary resuscitation)
content:
means a loss of cardiac output resulting in unresponsiveness and requiring cardiopulmonary resuscitation intervention, that is not associated with any medical procedure and is due to:
* cardiac asystole; or
* ventricular fibrillation with or without ventricular tachycardia.
The cardiac arrest must occur outside of a hospital and be documented by electrocardiogram (ECG).
If ECG evidence is not available, other medical evidence that unequivocally confirms a cardiac arrest has occurred will be considered. Such evidence may include ambulance or hospital medical records.
Cardiac arrest resulting from alcohol or drug abuse is excluded.
ai_summary: "Out of Hospital Cardiac Arrest" refers to a loss of cardiac output leading to unresponsiveness, requiring cardiopulmonary resuscitation, and must occur outside a hospital due to cardiac asystole or ventricular fibrillation (with or without tachycardia). Documentation of the event is required via electrocardiogram (ECG), or alternative medical evidence such as ambulance or hospital records may be accepted. Notably, cardiac arrests resulting from alcohol or drug abuse are excluded from coverage.

content: means the total and permanent loss of function of two or more limbs through Sickness or Injury causing permanent damage to the nervous system. This includes, but is not limited to, quadriplegia, paraplegia, diplegia and hemiplegia.
ai_summary: Permanent paralysis is defined as the total and irreversible loss of function in two or more limbs due to sickness or injury that results in lasting damage to the nervous system. This condition encompasses various forms of paralysis, including quadriplegia, paraplegia, diplegia, and hemiplegia, which may be relevant for determining eligibility for insurance benefits related to permanent disability.

content:
means the unequivocal diagnosis of degenerative idiopathic Parkinson’s Disease by an appropriate specialist Medical Practitioner, caused by degeneration of the nigrostriatal system and as characterised by the clinical manifestation of bradykinesia in combination with at least one of the following:
* rigidity; or
* rest tremor.
All other types of Parkinsonism are excluded (e.g. secondary to medication).
ai_summary: Parkinson’s Disease (permanent) is defined as a definitive diagnosis of degenerative idiopathic Parkinson’s Disease by a qualified specialist, characterized by bradykinesia and at least one additional symptom, either rigidity or rest tremor. It is important to note that other forms of Parkinsonism, such as those induced by medication, are not covered under this definition.

content: means the undergoing of surgery to remove an entire lung. This treatment must be deemed the most appropriate treatment and medically necessary.
ai_summary: Pneumonectomy refers to the surgical procedure for the complete removal of a lung, which must be considered the most appropriate and medically necessary treatment for the patient's condition according to insurance guidelines.

Subheading: Progressive and Debilitating Motor Neurone Disease
content:
means the unequivocal diagnosis of a progressive form of debilitating Motor Neurone Disease by an appropriate specialist Medical Practitioner.
The diagnosis must be supported by ancillary testing (e.g. clinical neurophysiology) and exclusion of other causes by imaging and appropriate investigations.
ai_summary: This section defines "Progressive and Debilitating Motor Neurone Disease" as a confirmed diagnosis by a qualified medical practitioner, supported by ancillary testing and the exclusion of other potential causes through imaging and relevant investigations. This definition is crucial for determining eligibility for insurance benefits related to this specific medical condition.

This section defines various severe medical conditions covered by the insurance policy, including Severe Burns (20% body surface area affected), Severe Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis (unresponsive to standard therapy), Severe Diabetes Mellitus (with specific complications), Severe Osteoporosis (with significant bone density loss and fractures), and congenital heart defects like Tetralogy of Fallot and Transposition of Great Vessels (requiring surgical intervention). Additionally, it outlines conditions such as Stillbirth (after 20 weeks gestation) and Stroke (resulting in a new neurological deficit), emphasizing the need for confirmation by a specialist Medical Practitioner and specific diagnostic criteria for coverage.

content:
Interim Cover is issued by us. This section sets out important information about Interim Cover. In this section references to ‘you’ or ‘your’ includes the life to be insured. We provide you with limited Interim Cover at no additional cost while your application is being assessed. Interim Cover is subject to:
* the terms and conditions which apply to the Plan(s) being applied for as set out in the Accelerated Protection Policy Document; and
* the additional terms and conditions for Interim Cover, as follows.

Interim Cover is subject to the Accelerated Protection Underwriting guidelines. This means we may be unable to verify the amount of Interim Cover (if any) until our assessment of your application is completed. Any conditions or restrictions that would have applied to your Policy based on our Underwriting guidelines will also apply to any Interim Cover claim you may make. A claim during the Interim Cover period will affect our assessment of your application and the terms of any Policy that we may subsequently issue to you or the Policy Owner. Any benefits payable under Interim Cover are payable to the Policy Owner, except where the Policy is structured through superannuation. If the Policy is to be structured through superannuation, we will pay the Benefit Amount directly to you. If Death benefit is payable, it will be paid to your legal personal representative. For Superlink IP and Superlink TPD applications, any benefits payable will be paid under the non-superannuation Policy. If you suffer a Sickness or Injury before your application being accepted by us (but after we receive your application), that Sickness or Injury will be taken into account in our assessment of your application once a decision on your Interim Cover claim is finalised.
ai_summary: Interim Cover provides limited insurance coverage at no extra cost while your application is being assessed, subject to the terms of the Accelerated Protection Policy Document and specific Interim Cover conditions. This coverage is contingent on the Accelerated Protection Underwriting guidelines, meaning that any claims made during this period may influence the assessment of your application and the terms of any future policy issued. Benefits are payable to the Policy Owner, with specific provisions for superannuation structures, and any pre-existing Sickness or Injury will be considered in the application assessment following a claim decision.

content: Interim Cover will start from the date we receive your fully completed, signed and dated application form. If we obtain the answers to the health and lifestyle questions in the application form directly from you, Interim Cover will start from the date we receive the answers to all of these questions. For Income Protection insurance, you must be Totally disabled and unable to Work at the end of the applied for Waiting Period to be eligible for the Interim Cover benefit.
ai_summary: Interim Cover begins on the date the insurer receives your completed, signed application form or, if applicable, the answers to health and lifestyle questions. For Income Protection insurance, eligibility for Interim Cover requires that you be Totally Disabled and unable to Work at the end of the specified Waiting Period.

Interim Cover for each Plan concludes at the earliest of the following events: the designated Plan start date, withdrawal of the application, 90 days after receipt of a fully completed application form, or notification to your financial adviser that the Plan has not been accepted.

content:
Plan type | Benefit
Life Insurance | If the life to be insured dies we will pay the Interim Cover Benefit for Life Insurance.
TPD Insurance | If the life to be insured becomes Totally and Permanently Disabled, we will pay the Interim Cover Benefit for TPD Insurance. The definition of TPD will be that applied for in the application except that where an 'Own Occupation' definition is sought the 'Any Occupation' definition will apply to Interim Cover.
Unless TPD insurance is Attached or Linked the life to be insured must survive for at least 14 days after the event that caused Total and Permanent Disability.
Critical Illness Insurance | If the life to be insured suffers a Critical Illness Standard condition listed in Section 2.3.1 of this PDS that does not have a '1' next to the named condition, we will pay the Interim Cover Benefit for Critical Illness Insurance.
Unless Critical Illness insurance is Attached or Linked the life to be insured must survive for at least 14 days after suffering the Critical Illness Event.
Child's Critical Illness Insurance | If the child to be insured suffers a Critical Illness condition listed in Section 2.5.1 of this PDS that does not have a '1' next to the named condition, we will pay the Interim Cover Benefit for Child's Critical Illness Insurance.
Income Protection | If the life to be insured becomes Totally Unable to Work, we will pay the Interim Cover Benefit for Income Protection insurance.
Interim Cover applies to the 'Totally Unable to Work Benefit and Super Contribution Option only. Interim Cover does not apply to any other benefits or any optional benefits under Income Protection.
ai_summary: The Interim Cover Benefit provides coverage for various insurance types: Life Insurance pays out upon the insured's death; TPD Insurance pays if the insured becomes Totally and Permanently Disabled, requiring survival for 14 days post-event unless linked; Critical Illness Insurance covers specified conditions, also requiring a 14-day survival unless linked; Child's Critical Illness Insurance applies similarly to children's conditions; and Income Protection pays if the insured is Totally Unable to Work, limited to the 'Totally Unable to Work Benefit and Super Contribution Option.' Interim Cover does not extend to other benefits or optional features under Income Protection.

Subheading: When we will not pay the Interim Cover
ai_summary: Interim Cover benefits will not be paid if a claim is made under the Interim Rollover Cover Benefit, if the underwriting decision prior to the claim would have declined coverage, if underwriting assessments cannot be completed due to the Sickness, or if the Sickness or Injury arises from excluded activities or conditions. Exclusions include claims related to suicide, self-inflicted injuries, substance abuse, criminal acts, or pre-existing conditions known to the insured. Additionally, coverage may be restricted if there is a failure to disclose accurate information during the application process.

content:
The Interim Cover Benefit we will pay will be the lesser of:
* the Benefit Amount applied for;
* the difference between the Benefit Amount applied for and any existing insurance with TAL or any other insurer which you stated on your application form is to be replaced;
* the reduced Benefit Amount that would be offered where, under our Underwriting rules, we would offer a lower Benefit Amount to that applied for;
* the reduced Benefit Amount the premium would purchase where we would apply a premium adjustment under our Underwriting rules; and
* the maximum amount payable under Interim Cover for each type of cover as specified below:

Plan type | Maximum Benefit payable
Life Insurance | $1,000,000
TPD Insurance | $500,000
Critical Illness Insurance | $500,000
Child's Critical Illness Insurance | $50,000
Income Protection | $10,000 per month, subject to adjustments, offsets and limited to a maximum of 12 months

The maximum amount payable is limited to a total amount payable of $1,000,000 for any one life to be insured in respect of all insurances, with TAL or any other insurer, under Interim Cover.
If an electronic application form is submitted by your financial adviser and your cover is accepted by our online Underwriting engine, these maximums do not apply, and we will cover the life to be insured based on the Benefit Amount applied for.
ai_summary: The Interim Cover Benefit payable is the lesser of the applied Benefit Amount, the difference between the applied amount and any existing insurance to be replaced, or adjusted amounts based on underwriting rules, with maximum limits set for various plan types: $1,000,000 for Life Insurance, $500,000 for TPD and Critical Illness Insurance, $50,000 for Child's Critical Illness Insurance, and $10,000 per month for Income Protection, capped at 12 months. Overall, the total payable under Interim Cover is limited to $1,000,000 per insured life, unless an electronic application is submitted and accepted, in which case the full applied Benefit Amount may be covered.

content:
The Interim Rollover Cover Benefit provides you with cover on the same terms as your accepted Accelerated Protection application while we are waiting for your nominated superannuation fund to transfer premium payment via rollover.

The Interim Rollover Cover Benefit is applicable where:
• the policy owner is Mercer Superannuation (Australia) Limited ABN 79 004 717 533, AFSL 235906, as the trustee for TAL Super; and
• the premiums are paid via rollover from your nominated superannuation fund.
ai_summary: The Interim Rollover Cover Benefit offers coverage under the same terms as your approved Accelerated Protection application while awaiting the transfer of premium payments from your chosen superannuation fund via rollover. This benefit applies specifically when the policy owner is Mercer Superannuation (Australia) Limited, acting as the trustee for TAL Super, and premiums are funded through rollover from the designated superannuation account.

content:
The Interim Rollover Cover Benefit starts when we agree to insure you and have received all the necessary requirements to enable us to issue your Policy (including any superannuation fund payment details).

The Interim Rollover Cover Benefit will cease upon the earliest of:
• the expiration of 30 days from the Interim Rollover Cover Benefit start date;
• the Plan start date as stated in the Policy Schedule; or
• the date you withdraw your application with us.

If your Policy has not been issued after the expiration of 30 days from the Interim Rollover Cover Benefit start date, the remaining balance of your Interim Cover will continue. Please refer to Section 10 to understand when your Interim Cover ends.
ai_summary: The Interim Rollover Cover Benefit provides temporary insurance coverage once the insurer agrees to insure you and receives all necessary documentation, including superannuation fund payment details. This benefit lasts for a maximum of 30 days, until the official Plan start date, or until you withdraw your application. If the Policy is not issued within 30 days, any remaining balance of the Interim Cover will continue, with further details available in Section 10 regarding the end of Interim Cover.

content:
The Interim Rollover Cover Benefit is subject to the terms and conditions which apply to the Plan(s) being applied for as set out in this PDS. Please note some additional terms and conditions as follows:
• It applies to a Plan which is funded by rollover and all Plans included in the same application.
• All claims will be subjected to the terms and conditions of the applicable Accelerated Protection Plan you applied for and where applicable, the special condition(s) that you’ve agreed to.
• If Life Insurance and/or TPD Insurance is structured through superannuation, any benefit payable under Interim Rollover Cover Benefit will be paid to the Life Insured or to the estate of the Life Insured as applicable.
• If Income Protection is structured through superannuation, any benefits payable under Interim Rollover Cover Benefit will be paid to the Life Insured or to the estate of the Life Insured as applicable. Benefits payable from the Policy start date will be paid to the Policy Owner.
• Any claim paid because of the Interim Rollover Cover Benefit will not affect our offer of insurance provided you have complied with your duty to take reasonable care not to make a misrepresentation.
• The Interim Rollover Cover Benefit does not apply where a policy being replaced is not cancelled.
ai_summary: The Interim Rollover Cover Benefit is applicable to Plans funded by rollover and is governed by the terms of the relevant Accelerated Protection Plan. Claims under this benefit will be paid to the Life Insured or their estate, depending on the insurance structure (Life, TPD, or Income Protection through superannuation), and will not impact future insurance offers if there is no misrepresentation. This benefit is void if the policy being replaced remains active.

content:
This Direct Debit Request Service Agreement (DDR Agreement) is issued by TAL (as an agent of MSAL in relation to TAL Super), to enable you to understand your rights and responsibilities as a new customer when making premium payments by direct debit. It allows TAL to debit your nominated account to meet the premiums for your Policy.

Please keep this DDR Agreement in a safe place for future reference.

How to make changes
Please give us at least 7 days’ notice before your next premium due date for either:
• altering any of your direct debit or financial institution details; or
• stopping or suspending any debits or cancelling the DDR Agreement completely.

If you do any of these, you will need to make alternative arrangements for future premiums to continue your Policy.

If you prefer you may contact your financial institution directly to alter, stop, cancel or dispute any debit. If you alter your direct debit details with your financial institution, your financial institution may alter your debit payment only to the extent of advising us of your new account details.
ai_summary: The Direct Debit Request Service Agreement (DDR Agreement) from TAL, acting as an agent for MSAL regarding TAL Super, outlines your rights and responsibilities for premium payments via direct debit. To make changes such as altering account details or cancelling the agreement, you must provide at least 7 days' notice before your next premium due date; otherwise, alternative arrangements must be made to ensure policy continuity. Additionally, you may contact your financial institution directly for any modifications or disputes related to the debit.

content:
Our commitment to you
We ensure that we:
• will give you at least 14 days written notice if there are any changes to the terms of this DDR Agreement; and
• will keep all information relating to your nominated financial institution account confidential, except where required for conducting direct debits with your financial institution, or otherwise as required by law.

Your commitment to us
If you do commit to a DDR Agreement, please ensure that:
• the account you have nominated can accept direct debits;
• all account holders for this nominated account agree to this Agreement; and
• that there are enough funds available in the nominated account, on the due dates, to cover the premiums. If there isn’t, you may incur dishonour fees from your financial institution and your Policy may be cancelled. Dishonour fees will not be charged by TAL.

If a premium due date falls on a weekend or a public holiday, we will automatically debit the payment on the next business day.

If you provide us, directly or indirectly, with new or updated bank account details (for payment through the direct debit system), these conditions will also apply to that request.
ai_summary: This section outlines the commitments of both the insurer and the policyholder regarding direct debit arrangements. The insurer will provide at least 14 days' written notice for any changes to the Direct Debit Agreement and will maintain the confidentiality of the policyholder's financial information, except as necessary for processing payments or as legally required. Policyholders must ensure their nominated account can accept direct debits, that all account holders consent to the agreement, and that sufficient funds are available to cover premiums to avoid dishonour fees and potential policy cancellation. Payments due on weekends or public holidays will be debited on the next business day.
